column11: Review Text

We were taken to this tea plantation by our driver and it was a nice little pit stop First, we had lunch as we had a long drive from Kandy.  A lot of the roads still had landslides from the cyclone a few weeks prior so it was slow going.  Lunch was buffet style and was LKR2,950 per person. We enjoyed the Sri Lankan curry items and the fruit.  √Ä la carte was only a little cheaper but western food and we didn't believe they would do this well. Second we went on a tour of the yea factory and plantation.  My wife was given some garb to dress up as a tea leaf picker; a nice little touch for the photo opp later.  You get about 10 mins to take photos in the plantation alongside other tea leaf pickers.  Do not take photo with them as they will expect you to pay them.  The lady guiding us had very good English and recited her speech to us.  We asked questions and she handled them well so she did have more than a cursory knowledge. Finally, you have a tea tasting.  Only the black teas are free.  We ordered the silver tip and golden tip teas and these cost about LKR350 each.  Before we left, we went into the shop to buy some souvenirs.  It's not particularly cheap even compared to Hong Kong where we came from but we're not coming back so it's fine.

We had a great experience at Bluefield Tea Factory! Our guide, J. Pragash, was very knowledgeable and friendly, explaining the tea-making process in an engaging and easy-to-understand way. We also got to make our own tea, which was such a fun and unique experience. Highly recommend stopping by if you‚Äôre visiting the area!

We had a great tour with Manseer who provided a perfect intro to the factory. The tour is tipped based and you should . You get an idea of how tea is produced and the different types available. The  tea shop is very commercial but has an excellent tea tasting experience.
We had a great experience here guided on a tour by Akram. He was very informative and friendly, we learnt a lot and would definitely recommend!!

column8: Overrated tea plantation tour and poorly trained staff
column11: Visited the tea plantation and they offered a tea safari in a jeep for uS$33 per pax for a 1.5hour Jeep ride in the plantation followed by tea picking, tea factory , tea tasting and a visit to buy their overpriced tea . There was a lot of confusion throughout the tour that spoilt the experience for us . The hero they provided was soaked in overnight rain water and the staff just look at each other wondering what to do, it was the initiative of our private driver who cleaned the seats before we got into their jeep . They brought us on a 1.5hour tour in the plantation that allowed us to see the tea fields, the housing where their workers stay , and 3 stops- over a bridge over a fast flowing river, a view of the rampoda waterfall , and a 360 degree view of their plantation and factory before they brought us back to the main area . We were board on the jeep . Thereafter, they did not know what to do with us and asked us what we wanted to do !! We mentioned tea tasting and they dumped 10 samples of tea on our table and asked us to taste them with weird labels on them . We asked them what these tea and labels were and the staff mentioned that it was not her job to explain what they were and the tea tour experience would informed us about the type and grade of tea . Hen we informed her that we had not taken the tour , then only she went into a detailed explanation of what the type of tea they were . However her body posture and demeanour basically informed us that she was just waiting to end our interaction with us . We decided henceforth not to buy any products from the tea company . The factory tour was interesting and was quite decent . They also forget to get us dressed and to pluck tea leaves . From this experience, we decided that it is not worth visiting this tea company . Should you visit any tea plantation, just take a tea factory tour, sip some tea and eat some cakes and move on at least for bluebell tea factory , not worth the visit .

column8: A great day out for all ages
column11: This was a truly great day out, enjoyed by both us parents and our two late teens. The jeep tour had some unbelievably stunning views. The tea picking and factory tour were informative, educational but also great fun. Much was buffet but with a lot of choice and very tasty food. And the tea tasting was a great finale. The staff were all incredibly friendly and helpful. Put your was with Swetha who was a very friendly and caring person but also very knowledgeable and who added lots of humour. But all the staff were wonderful. A really great day for all ages and one that you shouldn‚Äôt miss.
Lovely friendly staff, especially Nithmini. She gave a very clear explanation and it was fun to dress up. Tea was refreshing to try but expensive to buy.

Beautiful morning consisting first of Safari in jeep through the plantations and villages of tea growers, then gifted in a basket each of us was able to carry out the collection of leaves after listening to a brief explanation. absolutely not recommended!!! Boutique well stocked for tea purchases

column8: Popular tea factory tour and tasting in Nuwara Eliya
column11: It is one of the most popular tea factories in Sri Lanka and is located at the highland region of Nuwara Eliya. They have a big tea estates  around the factory and produce high quality tea that is exported as well. They offer a guided tour through the factory for visitors. You are able to see how tea is dried, pressed and produced. There's a tea tasting chamber with different types of teas. There show you the proper way of brewing tea. On completing the tour you will have the chance to purchase fresh boxes of tea leaves or even  small souvenirs from the tea factory‚Äôs gift shop. You can also enjoy a cup of hot, perfectly brewed tea and some pastries at the Bluefield‚Äôs restaurant before you leave. The restaurant is popular and it usually crowded. You have to wait for your order to be taken  and served.

We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Bluefield Tea Plantation. We did the jeep trip, factory tour, tea picking and tea tasting and found it well worth the money. Unfortunately for us due to the weather the jeep tour of the grounds were cloudy and wet but the staff members were so friendly and ensured we waited to see the waterfall (once clouds cleared a little). It was joyful to learn about the tea making process especially seeing how the traditional methods were still preserved in this factory. We loved picking tea leaves for ourselves and wish we had more time doing it. They have a great selection of teas in both the shop and with the tasty. All of which are very high quality and premium. Definitely recommend to anyone in the nearby area!

üçÉ Bluefield Tea Factory Discover the art of tea at Bluefield Tea Factory in the scenic hills of Ramboda. See how premium Ceylon tea is made, enjoy a guided tour, and taste fresh organic tea surrounded by beautiful mountain views.

Fantastic free tour of tea gardens, processing factory with personal guide. Informative descriptions, close viewing of machinery, tea picking experience and opportunity for taste testing. Fully recommended
Great  place to visit there tea garden and factory. Quality product and friendly staff. A great place for local and foreign tourists to enjoy a good cup of tea.

Beautiful experience the visit of the factory with the explanation of the process of harvesting and drying tea accompanied by a cute girl. Cute experience of being dressed like the locals and with the wooden basket made us try the experience of harvesting. They do not push to buy tea but we have all done it because the shop is also well stocked. We ate at the in-house buffet restaurant at a cost of 2950lkr and here too the experience was positive.
A beautiful place, a beautiful guide who in Russian met us and gave us an unforgettable tour of the factory. Thank you very much personally Jagath and Bluefield Factory
Jagath organized to us good excursions: show to us tea plantation and fabric. Jagath is telling interesting, recomendation!

Quite wondering if there will be a guy with flowers in the driveway, it requires separate attention.  The dining room is nice on the 3rd floor. The tour itself for 20-30 minutes is interesting, then the tasting, but the point of course is to take you to the store and there you bought tea. And the prices there, wow, we lived in Hikkaduva and we didn't see tea like that, but the point is the same, expensive. Less for the very nasty draught of workers you can't look at without regret, especially on the plantations, sticking to you, sticking tea leaves and tearfully asking for money.

A young hostess was waiting for us to visit this century-old factory that has rustic machines for drying tea leaves. English explanations of our guide on BOPG terms and white tea.  The prices in store are excessive but for tea lovers.....

As part of a tour of this factory First we reach the teapot plots with a guide from this factory who explains the picking, the 3 leaves, difference between white tea, green tea, then we enter the factory in operation to follow the different steps and finish with a tasting at the bottom of the store of three kinds, personally I was not convinced. I still bought a package, but I found the prices quite high

The tea factory was on our way and I wasn't even that interested in visiting it before. But I am glad to have done it and can really recommend it. The whole trip is worthwhile due to the beautiful and lush green surroundings. Endless mountains and tea plantations in the mist, I really enjoyed it! When you reach the factory, you get a wonderful tea smell that I couldn't get enough of! The tour of the factory and the great explanation in English I found very interesting, learned a lot of new things about tea that I had not known before. The subsequent visit to the caf√© for tasting as well as the shop was absolutely voluntary, as in any other shop in the city you can decide for yourself if you go in at all or buy something inside. Cannot understand these evaluations along these lines. At no point did anyone try to push you or sell anything. I enjoyed several types of tea and an excellent cinnamon roll (and two more for the way ;)) and bought two types of tea in the shop as a gift for home. Yes, the prices were a bit high for Sri Lanka, that is true. I don't know if the same varieties are available at different prices in the local supermarket. But the teas are extremely delicious, my husband and I enjoy every cup of them. Tastes really good and is also a nice gift and memory.

It was an honor to be able to touch this tradition: the tea harvest! They welcomed us warmly and we had the chance to observe and experience this magic! From the tea harvest, the visit of the Farm, to the tasting. We recommend a visit to the shop: the girls were super nice and helpful... indispensable to take some tea to take home!! üçÉ‚òïÔ∏è PS. Silver has won us over ‚ù§Ô∏è Anna and Davide, from Italy üáÆüáπ

We stopped at Bluefiled Tea Factory on our way to Ella and Oshida our charming young guide ensured that we had a wonderful visit. She shared her knowledge on the process, showed us around the grounds and also helped us choose tea to buy and drink!
Excellent experience in first time visit to a tea factory.  Knowledge i learnt about tea plantation.  Staff very kind and helpfull.

You can observe the process of making tea. Each group will have a one-person instructional Guide who will walk them through the factory. It is easy to understand because it explains slowly and carefully in English. The factory tour is free, and tips are not required, but when you give them to him, they receive them with a smile. It was a very old factory, but well maintained and clean. The adjoining shop also had a large selection of tea leaves to tea packs.

As a tea maniac, I was invited by a friend to tour this tea factory. And I was definitely not disappointed. Tea on arrival with sweets, then off to pick tea. Definitely this experience is worth it. And then a tour of the factory itself. I would never have believed how many procedures it takes to enjoy tea nicely at home. Everyone was so nice and of course in the shop I couldn't resist buying a few teas to take home. Which are still just as delicious. It's just a shame I can't enjoy them at the beautiful Bluefield location.

A local guide gave us a tour for a donation (we paid about 700 rubles). It's small but interesting. They showed all the stages of tea production in detail and answered all questions. After the excursion it was possible to taste tea (for a fee), we decided to try all 9 types. In the end, I liked green tea and pekoe the most. You can also buy dessert for the tasting. There is also a company store there with all types of tea in all kinds of packaging, with and without additives. We took several packages for gifts for ourselves) I was left with extremely positive impressions!

Very friendly welcome. Absolutely unobtrusive. The types of tea are explained patiently. The tasting went smoothly. All types can be tried. The Earl Grey is a dream. The prices are very good. Packed in packs of 5, you can buy gifts for several friends in one go. A walk through the plantation is very entertaining.

We were staying local to Bluefields Tea gardens and visited around lunch. Firstly we were greeted by Riyas who look us on a stroll through the tea fields and explained the process of tea production. He also showed us different types of leaves and offered to take a number of photos of us. We were then taken through the factory and saw some incredible tea making machinery. At the end, there was a tea gift shop which was extremely busy, filled with a number of flavours and types of brews. Overall Riyas was incredibly knowledgable and it probably benefitted us that we were in a duo rather than a big group. I‚Äôd definitely recommend this experience!

We made a special visit to tea plantations and a factory. The factory is 100 years old, it was still owned by the colonialists. Tea tasting is offered, a cup of the most expensive tea - gold and silver - costs 300 rupees. Nice place. A large store with a variety of tea products - both expensive and cheap teas, with and without additives, in souvenir packaging and without. We took a tour of the factory - it was informative.

Already at the entrance to the factory, stunning views of the tea plantations await you. A very picturesque serpentine road. Upon arrival, you are taken for a light tour of the factory. More precisely 2 workshops. Drying, sorting. The packaging is not shown. Then they talk a little about the types of tea. Everything takes 10-15 minutes. Next they lead to a cafe where you can taste all their teas. Well, then you can buy them in the store. The prices, of course, are higher than in a regular store, but not critical, as it seemed to me. There is tea for every budget. Everyone will find something for themselves.

We reached on a rainy evening, couldn‚Äôt see much due to the heavy rain but was good enough for the kids to enjoy the visit. We did lot of tea shopping, the display and services is very appealing. Nice coffee shop offering free EBT yet we ordered some deserts and they did taste good

The Bluefield Tea Garden company specializes in the cultivation, harvesting and also in the processing of premium Ceylon tea. You are taken on a guided tour around the factory. At the end of tour you are offered a taste of their home grown tea.

We visited Bluefield on a poya holiday. The factory didn't operate on that day but, a lady who works there gave us a tour. There was no charge for the tour but, we tipped the lady after the tour. They have a restaurant and an outdoor play area for kids. The snacks and tea at the restaurant were reasonably priced.

We came for a tour at the fields and the factory. We were lucky that Riyas showed us around. Very professional and knows a lot, let us ask questions and knows the explanations in several languages! You tip the guide at the end. During the walk in the field and the factory, the workers ask for money, some in a brutal way, which makes the experience not comfortable and awkward... The tea tasting is a fun experience!
No athmosphere, a 1500 rupee tour for only 10 minutes. There are way better options to visit a tea factory

I loved this place, watching and learning how so many people grow and manufacture so much tea in such an old fashioned way. The guide will take you through the entire process and if you are on site before 4 pm - the place will be in full flow. A great experience followed by tea sampling and a chance to buy as well. Enjoy‚Ä¶..
The guide was a young impressive woman names Tilakshi - she was very professional and her guidance was interesting and fascinating üßê

We visited Blue Field as part of our tour. This is one of the smaller factories in the area and offered a far more personalised experience as a result. Our host was only on her 2nd day of working there but was extremely knowledgeable and invited us to pluck some tea leaves, before a tour of the factory, and a tea tasting (R.s. 1,300). We thoroughly  enjoyed our visit and would highly recommend this estate.
Great tour guide and tea tasting at a factory with a lot of history. Try the Blue Moon tea, I brought so much home with me!
Knowledgeable staff showing how the tea is processed, then a chance to try some. A very well stock shop of various teas!
Nice demonstration of processing of tea & welcome tea afterwards. First time came to know about the varieties of Ceylon tea.

Visited on 20th February 2020 On our way to Nuwara Eliya from Kandy, we had a stopover at this Tea Estate to have a look at the tea manufacturing process and a hot cup of tea. The place is beautiful and the process is knowledgeable. The Cafeteria is very well appointed and takes you back to English Imperial Ruling days. Maintained in its original form this place is a welcome break from the long journey over a cup of tea. You can also buy milk-tea at SLR 120/- and there are pastries and snacks to choose from ranging about SLR 150 to 300/-. Products of the Tea estate are on sale at the souvenir shop. You may have  a look and decide accordingly. Do not miss this place on your way to Nuwara Eliya.

Guided by one of the nice workers we had a great tour trough the factory. The tours here are free. You can see the workers in the factory and take pictures, it‚Äôs nice if you give them something afterwards cause they only earn 750rs a day

Not my first tea factory walkabout but I still enjoyed hearing about it from our knowledgeable guide and the tea scent was heavenly. It was a nice, informative walk in the factory, before we were given some tasters in their tea room and offered to make a visit to their shop. Enjoyed the tea cake they sold too.

This wasn't my first tea plantation but they explained everything very well while also entertaining and well worth the visit. There was the usual shop with a good range of teas with staff that were attentive and not intrusive.

If your in any doubt go to this factory. The others don‚Äôt compare. The guides were amazing! We had a buffet lunch there too for 1000rs each ( with unlimited tea!) which was delicious. The best thing about the factory is there is a path that leads from directly behind the factory building on an amazing walk into the tea plantations and to the top of Ramboda waterfall! Do not miss this. The walk isn‚Äôt that strenuous and there are many paths to choose from. You can follow them all on google maps!

Food is nice , fresh and the service is classy. the restaurant having a simple and lovely layout which blends in with the sense and feel of the mountains. Staff polite and very much giving you the space needed to gather yourself after a long journey up the winding road. Just adjoining the restaurant there's the Tea Center which is arguably the finest in business .With such a large variety of teas ,so exquisitely packed make them ideal gifts to be dispersed, or gift own self with the myriad of blends, flavors on offer.Prices fair and reasonable and the effort at imparting knowledge about tea is admirable marketing. The tea factory in the adjacent  building and the fantastic tea gardens behind it make it a visit well worth the while.

As part of our tour of Sri Lanka we visited this fascinating tee plantation & factory. We were so fortunate to have Rasaq as our guide. What a friendly and knowledgable person. He told us he had been a guide for many years yet due to his boundless enthusiasm it seemed like we were his first ever tour. The factory is a trip back in time with 100 year old machinery and so much done by hand. So wonderful that the owners treated their staff like a big family.
Very good tea. Good service .you can see the tea factory and buy  tea packets . very reasonable price.

Blue Field Tea Gardens is an old factory established in 1921 during the British Clooney. They provide free tour and complementary cup of tea after the tour. Quick tour with one to one guide but useful to know enough about the tea plantation and processing. I liked the tour and their products. The price is normal as their brands not available in the market and you can only find it in their factory. Highly recommended for visiting.

It was ok ok museum. I have seen better versions in Munnar. They hardly show you the processing of tea or green tea. Give you 5 min brief and give you come complimentary tea and lead you to tore for buying variety of teas packed fancily.
We got a proper tour including tea plantas and the factor. After tour you can have a pot of black tee. So no tea tasting. Impressive place!
You can visit tea factory ,how to make tea in Sri Lanka, have restaurant and tea shop  you can flavour also tea nice photography location too
Good tour at Bluefield with their factory guide- very informative. Must try the tasting experience and tea cakes!

Our guide here was brilliant, a fascinating insight in to the process of growing and manufacturing tea as well as the various blends produced.  A definite must see on your trip and of course we enjoyed a pot of tea at the cafe here too.

If you have ever been to tea gardens or tea factory then you may choose to skip this. It is a decent place but the tea factory tour or view isn't worth it coz there are definitely much much prettier/ gorgeous tea gardens, in India at least. If you are around the area and have nothing much to do then no harm in giving it a try coz it is free and wouldn't take more than 30 minutes. I would rather sit and gorge at any of the valleys at nuwara eliya than recommend this place to anyone. Btw the cake is tasty and inexpensive!

We stopped by on our way to Ella as we wanted to understand further the unique, historical tea making process. Our tour guide was great, spoke great English with our private tour going for approximately 20 minutes. We walked throughout the entire factory at our own pace, see all processes. The tour was free, with a free cup of tea at the end. Even when buying some tea at the end we were never pushed or forced into anything. The entire team was great and it‚Äôs well worth it. On a side note you will notice the numerous signs for ‚Äòdumro tea factory.‚Äô We stopped here for the view which was amazing, but didn‚Äôt do the tour here, read the reviews before deciding to stop at this place...
There is a nice teahouse to try tea or other drinks. Guided presentation of tea preparation at the Pedro Tea factory.

A true tea field experience. Much better than other tea fields. You can visit this one on your trip down from Nuwara to Kandy. Spread across huge expanse of land, this tea factory, its tour and the showroom was setup much better than Handunugoda Tea Estate. The factory tour was given by their manager, who was well versed with the subject. He didn't rush into the presentation either. You will get a fair idea of the types of teas and how they are cultivated. The tea sample is served for free, sans the cake! The shop for purchase of tea is well laid out and you can get some real good packaging for gifting once you return to your home town. If you are an India, be watchful as the tea is quite expensive to buy here, just like elsewhere in SL. Date of Experience : March 2019.

Blue field Tea Factory is situated near Ramboda on the way to Nuwara Eliya. This tea factory is oldest (more than 90 years old) in Sri Lanka and they are manufacturing Black Tea only. Raw materials Tea leaves are plucked from surrounding Tea Garden. Staff members explained the manner in which tea dust are prepared and we have seen all equipments which are very old. Tea is prepared in a natural way without adding any chemical or other substances. Entrance is free.

Loved the experience Had a very enjoyable tour of the facilities @ Bluefield Tea Gardens which unfortunately only had minimal workings on our day . Loved the old machinery & seeing staff bag the tea . Our guide a young girl spoke brilliant English & was very informative. We enjoyed tea & cake @ a very reasonable price & also purchased some tea from the shop .

First of all, entrance is free! The factory is massive and full of history! The tea plantation covers a vast area too!!! Our guide was so knowledgeable that he explained very patiently and clearly everything we need to know about tea! Also treated to a complimentary tea tasting and of course we paid to try the best tea in the world- the golden tips! This is a must visit!
We were there for lunch & prices are average. staff are friendly but it took some time to service the food. however most of the items on the menu was not available. washrooms are clean.
In my opinion it's the best tea factory i visit in Srilanka , Good launch , very good tour in the factory,  dont forget to take gifts for your friends

I visited the factory,  the gardens and the cafe.. the blue outlook was pleasant. The tour guides in the factory were quite pleasant and taught us how the process works, so when you are done touring and sit down for a hot cuppa tea, you appreciate it just as much
Factory visit is quite detailed and to the point. Here you will know about the different variety of teas. I never heard about the white tea before. Neat and clean tea cafe. And a very good tea shop.
The experience was nice. The tea tastes amazing and the facilities were great. The environment was even awesome. The people are really friendly and kind.must visit place.
Visited this tea factory on way to Nuwara Eliya.  Saw the tea leaves drying . The sorting and fermentation processes were closed. Finally departed. We couldn't get guide as all were busy with whites.

Factory is fantastic and surrounded by breath taking view. Our tour guide Mr. Mohammad Sideeq was very friendly and professional. He provided us a lot of information about tea manufacturing process. The only negative thing is the overpriced tea products.

Blue Field Tea Gardens is such an interesting place.  You learn all about the picking of tea leaves and all the machinery that is involved with the sorting of the tea.  Then, you get to taste the tea!

You can't visit Sri Lanka without going to see a Tea Plantation, right ?! So we were really pleased that our trip included a stop over here. Obviously there are lots of tea factories all over Sri Lanka, and we only visited this one, so cannot compare to any others, but I assume they are all very similar. The tour takes you round the tea processing factory, as they explain the various stages of processing and different types of tea, and includes a cup of tea afterwards in the nice looking restaurant. There is also the obligatory shop to purchase the vast number of teas from, much of which seemed a little high in price considering they made it on the premises (?). The teas in the fancy packaging seemed quite expensive and we felt it was a bit of a tourist rip-off, so we bought some of the cheaper variety to take home as a souvenir ! The whole thing took approximately one hour, which is just about right. I was a bit disappointed that this  didn't  include a tour of the actual tea fields which surround and rise up into the hills around the tea factory. However....  If you ask nicely then the tour guide will let you take a sneaky detour round the back into the plantation fields, where you can take photos of the tea and also some of the tea pickers - who will gladly pose for the photos if you give them some Sri Lanken Rupees (LRK) tips ! Whilst we enjoyed the experience, we felt saddened and astonished when we saw and found out about the quality of life and working conditions the workers were still enduring in the 21st Century. None of them seemed to have any protective equipment, ear defenders, goggles, hard hats... despite working around noisy, fast moving and potentially dangerous looking machinery. Many of them were not even wearing shoes !!!! Apparently the tea pickers earn something like just 500 rupees, which is just over ¬£2, per day. And in return for this, they get very hard and rough skin on their hands from picking the leaves all day. Not the best life to live, is it ?! So if you visit here and they do pose for photos, please be generous and give them a tip !  If just 2 tourists give them just  ¬£1  tip for some photos, then that doubles their daily wage !
A tour of the facility was worthwhile and gave a good understanding of the processes.  We then went to the cafe and enjoyed a cup of tea and the opportunity to taste some different teas.
Would definitely recommend the free tour if you‚Äôre in the area. The cup of tea afterwards is a lovely treat and we also enjoyed some cake from the cafe! Lovely shop too.

Hi Guys and it's nice location and located this factory with beautiful view behind tea plantation and mountain view... You can taste best flavour cup of tea in here.... They have different tea flavours with best... Thank you...
I liked this tea factory, many variety of teas, they make six type of teas. You can buy teas directly from this place with acceptable prices compared (I was told) with Colombo.
Really enjoyed our visit to Bluefields, our guide was excellent. Tour was finished off with a lovely cup of tea.

Easier to reach, since this is roadside. They have built a path, so that you can walk along it and view the tea making process in steps. Clean factory. They also have a tea boutique where you can buy tea or drink a cup
The tour was really interesting. We got shown step by step the processes of making tea. The guide spoke perfect English. The tea was nice to taste in the restaurant after.

We visited on our way to Nuwaraeliya. It was crowded with tourists and some workers are busy in explaining to them. Could have used videos, leaflets, proper guiding notes for everyone to visit. Visited the restaurant too. Buffet was available around Rs 990. apart from the buffet Ala carte  menu was not had enough options

We took a short tour with an english guide, He took us in a tea factory, while the production didn't worked. The tour was short and very informative. I missed some information about tea picking (how it is picked,...). At the end they show you the variety of teas, but you don't get the tea tasting. This is a big mistake. You must buy the tea, to taste it. It is not so expensive, but still, at the end of tours like that, you always expect some tasting, so that you know what to buy. It is the whole purpose of it. So at the end they lead you to the shop, but still, you didn't try it, so it is hard to buy. The prices here are OK, but for our taste there could be some basic black tea for cheaper price. Try to smell the Blue Moon tea, it is really great. Unfortunatelly we didn't buy it here, because we hoped to get it somewhere else, but we didn't. So buy it here, if you want to have it. There is also a restaurant in the facilities, but we didn't try it. You can also have a lunch there.

A lovely young lady showed us through the tea factory, which smelled wonderful. She was able to answer some questions but couldn't answer when I started talking tea grading and first flush tips etc. Sadly there was no tour of the plantation. Then it was a complimentary cup of their lowest grade tea and a shop. The tea is quite expensive and I bought some here and then discovered much better prices at the supermarket. However I was very happy that I did splurge and bought the evening tea - OPA - as it is truly delicious. Good quality, big leaves and doesn't require any milk or sugar as it's that good. I bought it in the cheapest container they had as the prices start to skyrocket when the packaging gets fancy. It's a nice setup they have here.
The tour was quite good and we learned a lot about the process of how tea is made. It is something to do in Sri Lanka and why not? All part of the experience of such a beautiful country.

It is just a hault on the way to Nuwara Elliya. The short tour is not very informative. It is slightly aromatic though. They take you to those parts which arent operational at that time, so we get to see only stationary machines. Tea tasting is also a long wait procedure. Tea i felt is expensive but the variety in packing is huge.

Really it‚Äôs amazing because this tea factory is the place that we can see the tea making process very closely even always we can breath the tea smell. Also very good taste of tea and very good price to buy other then black tea to home.

This was a relaxed & participatory tour of a tea plantation following the process from picking through to brewing and enjoying a cup of tea. Women are extensively employed from picking through the processing of a very hands on production. We started with trying our hand at picking the leaves. Staff in the shop were helpful with information about the different teas available.

The factory was closed since it was sunday, but a guide took us around and explained the process how tea is made from the leaves. The explanation could have been slightly more detailed & covered things like ft flush etc. It is basically a sales outlet for the world famous Sri Lankan tea & has a very good collection.

Enjoyed my short trip to the tea factory. Got to see some action in the factory ; the smell of the leaves being crushed was great. There were quite a few women working in there and I learned a lot about production and the selling at action. The shop is probably quite over priced but there‚Äôs a nice cafe area to try the tea and get some food. A cup of silver tip tea was 170 rupees and was a new experience. Worth visiting if you want somewhere that isn‚Äôt too busy with tourists.

The format here is the same as other tea factories around the area where you get a free tour and tasting n the hope that you spend money n their shop. As this was our third scheduled tea factory on our day tuk-tuk tour of the area so we elected not to go in but took a walk through an area of the plantation behind the factory. It was really enjoyable to get up close to the tea shrubs and take in the scenery.

So, we actually learned a lot. We were met by Rasaq, a guide to the plantation and the factory. I guess that he gives the stort numerous times during a normal day, but nevertheless he was fun, vivid and clearly excited on the story of this old, still manually operated tea-factory. We liked the story, too. And we liked it so much, that we bouft more-than-normal quantities of tea. Which we enjoy today, back home, not least due to the fantastic story. Go visit, andenjoy

We had booked onto a "Highlights Tour" with Viator, whom I would not recommend, as a tour operator, but the actual trip to the tea gardens was an excellent experience. We were taken around by a very knowledgeable lady and given a history and understanding of how tea is made, which was fascinating. The machinery used, was amazing, and the whole place gives you a real insight. We saw tea pickers, and learnt of their dedication to their job. The cafe and shop are both well worth a visit - prices very competitive, and of course, we had more understanding of what tea to buy, according to our own tastes. I would thoroughly recommend a visit here, but not through Viator!.  Get yourselves there by local transport, for a thoroughly enjoyable experience.
The guide was very informative and was very patient when answering our many questions.  We learned a great deal!

This is a great place. It‚Äôs in a beautiful setting, the factory surrounded by tea fields and when the sunshines, it looks fabulous. A great little tour of the factory ‚Äì just the right length with the right amount of information - and then a complimentary cup of tea You can then browse the tea for sale in the shop without any pressure to buy. Of course, because there is no pressure and you take your time, you buy a lot more than if someone is looking over your shoulder all the time. A great place to stop en route from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya.

Nice and clean place to stop for a tea on the way to nuwaraeliya. I like the milk tea its hot and delicious. I went with my foriegn friends as they have a good quality tea shop. There are many varieties of tea available with a good price. If you like to go to see the tea factory just a walking distance. We were there abouy 30 minutes to get relax and to buy tea.

An old British era tea factory.  Since our visit was on the day after National, they didnt have fresh plucked leaves for processing. Only finishing section was working.  You can get a free cup of black tea.  You can also buy different varieties of teas which are sold in the outlet attached to it.

Very informative.must see enroute to Nuwara eliya.lot of tea plantations. Learnt about entire process, different types of teas .no entry fees. They offer complimentary tea 1 cup.the special teas green,gold,silver are chargeable. Theres also a shop to buy the different types of teas ,nicely packed as gifts .prices vary

If visiting a tea factory then there is no better, good to see the tea making process and then to visit the on site tea room for tea and in our case we visited in afternoon so we had cake. Also bought a box of tea to bring home all at good prices. Very helpful staff
Very nice experiences you can get here with some of tea plantation and also tea tast of ceylone.hope to see all there

I have been to other tea estates/factories, but the tour here was the best; instructional and interesting, learning about the different grades of tea. Topped off with a nice cup of tea and the opportunity to buy tea to take back home

Sweet and informative... A quick tour that gave us the basic insight into the workings and processes at this typical tea factory.  We had a nice friendly guide who showed us around for a fee and enjoyed a cup of tea at the end of the tour.  The aim is to steer the visitor towards the onsite boutique, which was lovely but maybe a bit pricy... The cakes in the lovely tea rooms are worth checking out!
Lovely tour with enthusiastic guide. Photos allowed. Lovely seating outdoors to sample the tea. Would recommend.

Interesting tour of the processing plant to see the different stages that the leaves of tea go through in order to be tea leaves!  Don't think the process or the machines have changed in donkeys years.  Good explanation of the different teas they produce, followed by a complimentary cup of tea!  Worth visiting
well worth a visit.  fascinating to understand how tea is processed.  a great experience, well worth visiting

On the Way To Nuwaraliya From Kandy, We Stopped here for a Break This Place has Different types of Tea and Fresh tea with Fresh Smell. The restaurant offers some Good food as Well, But more than the food a Piece of Cake and fresh Tea would make the day
The tour in the bluefield tea gardens was all right but not as good as other tours I‚Äôve done in Sri Lanka. Their tea is very good though and I recommend you taste their chocolate cake.

We were not set on any single tea plantation and went to this one at the recommendation of the driver who had picked us up at the train station. A free cup of tea is given before or after your tour, and the factory is small enough that you can get pretty close to the equipment and really understand the process. You can walk the fields behind the factory too, and there is an AMAZING view of the valley if you make it over the first hill.
This place is good to stop over when you are travelling from or to Kandy. Worth of doing a tour and pure tea

We had a great tour of the factory, just the right length for us and the kids. Interesting learning about the different teas and how they are produced. We saw most of the machinery working, our tour was in the morning. We bought quite a bit of tea in the shop,  thought the price was fine.  The cafe was great with lovely free tea and reasonably priced silver tip tea.  The cakes and samosas were superb and the staff were all very friendly
We got a tour of the tea factory which was educational.  There is a restaurant and gift shop.  The food in the restaurant was inexpensive and generous portions.

Definitely one of my tops 5 things to do in Sri-Lanka. We have enjoyed our visit to the factory and learning so much thing regarding the history of tea. As a Tea lover is was nice seeing and learning about the process of creation, not forgetting all Womens and mans hands behind the process, because it‚Äôs not something easy. Please don‚Äôt forget to be respectful and nice with those hard-working people ( a tip will be much appreciated )s
Jagath , the person who gave free demonstration as very useful. Enjoyed golden tip tea at the restaurant. Must watch place for Ceylon tea lovers
You will see this place on the way to Nuwara-Eliya, so it is a good place to take a break from the long drive. They have a nice restaurant with delicious food and clean washrooms.

On 08/01/2019 I was at the blue field tea garden factory. I bought silver tips, premium white tea ( batch N 101009) When I opened the tea box at home, I was very disappointed. Premium class tea has the smell of rotting hay, the smell of mold is clearly audible. You can not deceive people. tea costs 5780 rupees . I threw it away unfortunately.

As we had already done a plantation tour elsewhere we just went to the cafe. It was lovely sitting out in the garden enjoying tea and cake.  I ordered a tea tasting session,  600rs for about 10 different full cups of tea.  It gives you a chance to work out which ones you actually like. The tea in the shop is expensive ($35aud for 500g of orange pokoe - can buy it in Australia for $18 per kilo). Come here to taste all varieties of tea,  but buy tea's elsewhere.

The tour was just the right length for me - brief but informative. Despite the signs prohibiting photography, I was allowed to take photos. Be aware though, that as soon as I snapped a pic including one of the factory ladies, the hands came out for donations - oops. At the end of the tour I was dropped off at the cafe/gift shop for a free cup of lower grade tea. Higher grade teas are available for a reasonable fee. No pressure, no sales pitch.

Informative free tour. Can wander the tea plantations afterwards on own. Couldn't find any tea pickers in the plantation when we went. Complimentary tea - tried the strongest tea (Dust No 1), which was a great cuppa. Great and cheap cakes in the tea shop.

The bluefield tea factory is on the way towards the hotel which we chose in Nuwara Eliya. On arrival there a tour guide gives you a very small talk around the factory and then you get a complimentary tea to taste. Also there is a plantation for you to have a look at and walk through. They do explain well the tea process and also the grading of the tea. There is also a shop which you can buy the teas as well. However do have a look at the pricing in some cases for a little bit more money you get much more tea. Also the gift sets are a bit pricey. There is food available but where the food is there is also some flies there...

The Tea Factory is not functioning well and only few machines are operating. But you will be able to see the machines. Basically you will be able to get basic idea of tea Factory. This tea factory seems old but still functioning. If you met any operator guy you will be able to get brief guiding. But most probably they will provide group guide, not individual guide. No entrance fees charged. They have standard restaurant and serving buffet. Standard buffet and food teats is not bad. They have shop which you can buy only their production. Tea is quality and expensive than other outlets. Regards Buddika Fernando

A great place to go and learn about tea . Black white & green . You start with a tour of the factory and learn about the process from picking all the way threw to packing for distribution. A very knowledgeable tour we learn a lot about tea. You are then of too the cafe for a free tea or samples (at a cost ) Then the gift shop for tea sales and purchase . A great hour or so whilst on the way thru . Definitely worth a stop in .

They offer a tour around the factory to show you how tea is made, with a lady as the narrator. As a Chinese I already know about that, but what surprises me is the lady taught me about the word "Pekoe" (tea leaf grading). It's originated from a Chinese word and used globally, but I never heard of it back in China. Indeed you learn something new everyday.

It was a friendly tour and a cup of tea given at the end but wouldn‚Äôt return here. Would prefer more of a personal experience and taken to see tea growing, more interactive exhibits to view in own time rather than being rushed through. We were paired with another family who were french and struggled to translate quickly enough so one lady walked off mid your after being told we had a time limit of 20 mins to get around the factory and see the whole tour. I think it was actually quicker than that! It was great to see machinery working and the factory workers. Wouldn‚Äôt liked to have a more personal experience, perhaps to do a bit of our own tea picking and the process ourselves- would be happy to pay more to do this.

This is one of the few places where you are taken through the entire tea leaf making process free of charge. We were assigned a young guide Aushika who spoke good English and took us through the entire process. We learnt about the various types of tea. At the end of the tour we were asked to choose a tea that we‚Äôd like to taste  at the tea room nearby. The BOPF tea was free but we had to pay to try the other tea which were reasonably priced. The chocolate cake was delicious.

We were guided around by a lovely guide at no cost and sampled their tea at the cafe. You must try their pastries since they are fresh and exquisite. In comparison to the other tea factories I strongly recommend that you visit this ones

Well located on the climb to Nuwara Eliya with ample parking for vehicles. Good snacks and EXCELLENT TEA, Very pleasant staff who gives good service. Sadly, overcrowded and getting a place to sit may be an issue.

This was a great visit. In November, as low season, it was not at all busy and we had an interesting and informed guide. There is a very pleasant cafe and attractive, well stocked shop but maybe it is just me - I don't like being followed around by someone on my shoulder as I browse.

We came to visit Blue field just because our driver said it's one of the few places where they don't charge an entrance fee and explain the process well (though you are expected to pay a few hundreds of rupees as tips). We met our guide who knows a few Chinese and explained the process pretty clearly, though the whole visit lasted no longer than 15min. They then take you to a tea tasting section which you can enjoy a free cup of BOPF (kind of 2nd-but-last grade for tea bags. Noted we we to Damro later for tea and they claimed to use BOP which is 1 grade higher). The price of tea there is indeed 3 times more than what you can find in the supermarket or central markets (like in Nuwara Eliya and Kandy). Strangely they will tell you within the same grade the tea inside the packages are the same, but prices do varies a lot with different packages... What I learnt is that bigger brands like Lipton, Dimah, Mackswood are all sourcing teas from this tea garden partially so you can say what you buy out in the market also have no big difference in quality. What we don't really like about the place though, is the garden. We took a walk around and 1 old man approached us with a bunch of freshly picked tea leaves. Right next to him was another woman. They were not actually working, no sack no tools... They just ask you to take pictures of them and expect you to pay. Worst of all, after we gave them each 20Rs they are not happy with the amount and asked for more. If you really want to see the working tea puckers go to Pedro or Damro where you have better views and real puckers. Maybe because nowadays fewer people visit Pedro , I found the tea puckers so much more authentic and friendly than this one. They don't ask for tips. And when they receive some, I can see the real appreciation in their eyes. We ended up shooting nothing of the tea puckers in BlueField. Maybe also ask your guide or driver to see if they know that which parts of gardens have finished tea picking.

Its all about knowing how tea is made. They have 100 year old equipment, robust time tested process & limited modernisation to give out great tea. A must place for tea lovers : Green, black, flavoured, white : you name it. Accepts all major cards. The Lunch organised by our tour Operator - Veena World was also of good quality.
The tea factory was closed when we visited so could not see the functioning But the guide gave us a tour nevertheless Had complimentary tea which was yummy Go for it

Well, I never realised what went into making a cup of tea!  A very worthwhile hour spent visiting the factory and learning the various processes, followed by a much appreciated tasting.  Beautiful terraces of tea bushes - the surrounding countryside is stunning.

Nice cool place. Informative tour of tea process n a nice place to chill for tea n some cakes. Food available at 2nd level. Prayer place available for Muslims. Finally the highlight, shopping for various kind of teas from healthy white tea to fruity flavored teas.

The tour may be more interesting during an actual workday but we visited on Sunday. Still, one problem with tours lies with their organization--considering the small space with multiple groups and the resulting verbal competition of their guides. I have experienced better presentations at other plantations.

The guide for The tea factory Mr. Abdullah was very good and proficient. He covered all the details related to tea processing Later we took some snaps of spectacular views from tea estate On return they provide a complementary black tea and restaurant is good with few simple eateries Overall a not to be missed experience
100% run an managed by women... great!! Tip: go into the fields and pick some tea on your own. Just ask your guide, it‚Äòs fun!!
There is a a functioning tea factory which you can visit. Good selection of tea to purchase. We had milk tea and it was tasty.
We did a brief tea tour here in October 2018.  It was very interesting seeing how tea is made, and what's involved.  Staff were very friendly.

The views are lovely all around this area and seeing the people working in these fields is hard work for them. I was expecting a big factory workforce and for it to be full of dust totally the opposite, this factory had 300 staff that work at different shifts and clean as anything. It was interesting information about how our Tea is produced but then someone else puts their name on it after all the effort the staff have to do just to collect it and process it. At least you get a descent copper whilst you are travelling around Sri Lanka.

The property is spread in acres. Janu, our tour guide showed us around well. She explained well in English. The tea was delicious. The ambience of the restaurant and cozy private shacks were welcoming. They had olden style machines in display and some of the active machinery were still operational since the inception of the factory.

On the way to Nuwara iliya , we stopped and visited Blue field tea factory. Guide one of their factory staff explained tea making process very well. We did visit to tea garden which is just behind the factory. Compound also includes a restaurant and showroom. You can enjoy black tea free, if you want to buy you can buy from showroom cum shop.

It's a working tea factory which is neat to see how it's all done. We had a well explained tour of the facility and how it all works, finishing with a lovely cup of tea and some tasty cake. It's a wee way out of town, but chances are you would do this on a tour or if self driving while visiting the waterfalls. You can walk the fields, just expect if you take pictures of the workers you should give them some rupees - 50 or so.

My husband and I visited Bluefield as part of a day trip around Nuwara Eliya, and it was the highlight of the day. We started with a really informative tour of the tea factory itself, followed by a tea tasting. We could have had a free cup of tea each, but opted to pay a small amount (600 rupees, about ¬£3) to try all the different types of tea - we were pleasantly surprised to find that this even included both types of the famous white tea, golden tips and silver tips (delicious!). We were so impressed that we bought quite a lot of tea in their shop - which was much more reasonably priced than the other tea factory we had visited earlier on that day. Altogether a great experience.

It was a very interesting tour for us. This was the very first time I got to know about the tea plantation. Finally we know the process, it was very educational. We went to the around the factory with a really knowledgeable guide. It was actually exciting to study how the tea is made. There is small restaurant inside the factory our friend Ilham bought some cakes for us and waiter gave a free plan-tea for us. There are many of tea estates and tea factories on the way to Nuwara-eliya but our tour guide and  our friend Mr.Ilham Rameez recommend this place absolutely it‚Äôs an amazing experience in my life .At the end we would like to thank everyone.
There are plenty of tea estates around nuwara eliya which offers free tea for testing and visit to their factory...
Nuwara eliya weather is apt for tea farming and you will find many tea estates here. Great to view how they make tea

We had a personalized tour of the Tea Factory and how it operates and this was recommended to us by our driver. It was a very interesting tour for all of us. This was the very first time i got to know and all these days i was wondering how tea is looking black in color while all plantations are fully green. Now that i know the process, it was very educational.

We first visited Damro and it was great. Great view, silver service tea (free) and tour of the working factory. BUT then we went to Blue Fields and were disappointed by the tea (we paid for) and poor service. Not recommended.

We sampled the various tea and were shown around the factory with a really good guide. It was really interesting to learn how the tea is made and the different process to arrive at the various teas. We tipped the guide at the end.

This was the first time we visited a tea factory and it was interesting to learn about the lengthy process to make tea. Our guide was excellent, no charge for the tour, but we gave our guide a small tip. We would have loved to go into the fields where they were picking leaves, but it was raining so didn't, so not sure this would usually be part of the your.

Fabulous experience visiting the tea plantations and seeing the lady tea ‚Äúpluckers‚Äù in the fields working very hard for very little.  Long days and minimal pay, but happy and polite and only too willing to let you have a photograph with them. They start work early and work until late and for this they get an approximate payment of ¬£4/¬£5 per day. There is a minimum amount of tea leaves that have to be stored in their back packs in order for them to get paid. However, they do get cups of tea and have a short break.
This factory on the way to Nuwaraeliya from Kandy . They give you guided factory tour. Allows you to buy tea from shop.

I was not expecting much but the free guide of the oldest tea factory in Sri Lanka was actually very informative Seeing how they dry the leaves such a tedious process. all hand picked!! the tea tasing was also fun I hadn't rallied that all tea comes from the one plant cakes were ok but it was a nice thing to do in the heart of tea country

An interesting insight into a working tea factory. It could be a really good tour. It is free but actually I would rather have paid something and got a tea tasting or something as well. The factory is dimly lit and has no real soul- very odd feeling inside. Shop is ok and plenty of stock. Be very careful if the tea ladies usher you out to the fields, they will let you take their picture but agressively demand money afterwards. This is awkward for you and if they are caught can be sacked so don't do it.

Situated around 20km outside Nuwara Eliya Bluefields Tea is well worth the drive to get there. You can have a free tour of the factory where you will learn about how tea is grown, harvested, and processed into the product tea drinkers know and love. At the end of the tour you can choose to have a free cup of tea. The shop has a lovely selection of cakes (you pay for these). The Tea Shop has quite a collection of different teas from the Estate for purchase for a reasonable amount - price varies depending on the type of tea you buy and how much. My biggest challenge was choosing. It takes 45 minutes to 1 hour to get there by Tuk Tuk - the road winds up and down hills and valleys. It's a picturesque drive - you can see tea plantations and workers; and spectacular scenery. Allow 2-3 hours, it's worth it.
Just amazing!! To closely see and understand  how tea is made in Sri Lanka is breathtaking and the view of the tea fields is a cherry on top.

Find out which is your favourite tea flavour. Great tour of the estate followed by tea tasting. I did a great shop of teas in the shop for my tea crazy family at home! Really enjoyed the visit. thank you Samantha

We went to Bluefield Tea Gardens on our way to Nuwara Eliya. As soon as we entered a representative took us to the factory and explained us the process of tea making, after which they served us a cup of black tea which was complimentary. You can also order from the coffee shop menu if you want anything else. They have a store where you can buy different types of tea. You can also visit the tea garden to take pictures, but unfortunately we were not able to go there as it was raining heavily.

We had a great tour of the tea production process by a very knowledgeable guide.  Happy to answer questions and a really interesting tour.  Well worth the visit. A nice location for a lovely cup of tea and a great tea shop for purchasing gifts/souvenirs of your visit.

We went there recently and had a wonderful experience of warm welcome and perfect cup of tea!!!. Simply it was heavenly. A good place for a short break during your trip to Nuwara Eliya. The Staff is pleasant, supportive and attends to your needs immediately. You can select different varieties of Sweets or Savories to accompany your Tea.

We had a very nice explanation about the tea production process from A-Z, which was very interesting and free. I finally understood the actual process tea goes through, from the picking of the leaves and up to the tea bag in my cup...  nice

Lovely scenic drive to plantation. Plantation guide was excellent. Really interesting to see how tea is produced and to see the inside of the building which is in original condition and bar one modern machine the process of making the tea hasn't changed. Free entry and tour and cup of tea at end of tour. Nice to have a walk around plantation to see the tea bushes and the workers picking them.

We visited Mackwood (now knows as Damro) straight after visiting Blue Field, as it was on the way to our hotel in Nuwara Eliya. The tour at Blue Field is much better, as the process of tea making was explianed in detail in 10-15 minutes where as it only took 5 minutes at Mackwood. However, the setting at Mackwood is much nicer and for pictures. The tea from the shop is also cheaper at Blue Field. If time allows it, try both as it takes 15-20 minutes to travel between both.

We hired a van and the trip down the winding roads amidst the tea farms are a great view itself. The area is a little warmer than central. The factory location itself has a great view of the surrounding mountains and tea patches. You will know almost everything about Srilankan teas if you take the tour through. All then processes, varieties of teas etc. The guide there do it passion, for zero charge. But better give her some tips. Out in the field tea leave pickers work for a lesser daily rate. If you inquire a photo with them it would be nice to tip them. Theres a restaurant, souvenir shop and tea cafe. The lunch at the restaurant was of good quality.

Our guide was very informative and interesting.  Unfortunately we visited on a Monday which is not the best day as no picking takes place on a Sunday and therefore most of the machines were not functioning.  Despite this we still learnt a great deal about how tea is produced and then enjoyed a cup of black tea.   The shop has a great range of souvenirs too.
Nice place to.sit and relax . They have variety of tea to explore and drink. You will.love this place

This tea factory was recommended by our driver. So glad we made the trip here. The tea pickers have been located here for centuries and I believe this is one oft he oldest tea factories around with machinery going back over 100 years. Our guide was very informative and gave us a thorough walk through and explained the tea making process. The tea tasting at the end was Devine and for less then ¬£10 you get to sample all the tea which is made. A must visit, if you are in Nuwara Eliya.
this is tea factory en route to elliay , they concentrate only for the people who buy the tea products there. i bought a tea packet its not good

One of the best tea factories in Nuwar Eliya!! We had a tour of the factory, later we were guided to the tea lounge and were given complementary tea. The location is delightful, surrounded by hills covered in tea plants. We had a personal tour from a young woman who took a lot of pride in what she did. She gave an interesting tour explaining the history and tea making process of the factory. She also explained about the different grades of tea and what constitutes "quality". As we are tea lovers we found this fascinating. Afterwards we drank tea in the cafe and bought some to take home as gifts. I do not exagerate when I say that this was the best tea I have ever had.  A real treat. I might go back there just to stock up.
Nice tea factory on the way to Nuwara Eliya They take you round the factory and offer free cup of tea Black tea and Green tea available for Sale

Great intro to tea making.  The tea smell was amazing in the factory,  like the tea had perfumed the wood !  Tea and cakes were delicious;  you pay for the cups of tea and cake rather than the tour and unlike other places I read of there was no pressure to buy tea to take home (although we did)

Stumbled upon this Plantation whilst travelling from Kandy to Yala. This place is definable worth visiting. Free Guided Tour which really explained just how much goes into making and processing tea. Really nice Tea room offering a free cup of Black Sample Tea. Also a shop selling all the different teas produced by the Grower. As I said there is no entry charge so its customary to thank the Guide with a small tip. Definitely worth a Visit

Lovely tea field/ factory. They offered a very informative tour of the factory and how the tea is collected and produced. No tip is expected at the end unlike some free tours. We received a free cup of black tea at the end of the tour in the cafe. We also ate he buffet lunch for 800 rupee per person, which was great. Offered lovely views in the restaurant. Highly recommend

Went to Bluefield after recommendations from my SL cousins. The factory tours was really nice, with the guide and the factory workers explaining us the different stages of the process. The smell of toasted tea leaves that hits you the moment you step into the building is welcoming and soothing. I really enjoyed the tea tasting afterwards and bought a couple of teas at the shop! It is definitely worth a visit! Bonus: tea factory tour and sampling of one variety is free!

As mentioned by many - much better than the rather touristic Damra factory - they do take time to go through the tea manufacturing process and allow questions / pictures. Close by you can also take pictures of ladies picking tea. Tour is free of charge so please leave tip for the good quality guide or for ladies picking tea if you take pictures

We did the guided tour of the tea factory which was very interesting.  Even our kids enjoyed it.  We saw the workers in the factory.  The downside was that they approached us to pose and then claimed money for the picture.  We then had a cup of tea and everything was free.  They have a nice boutique where they help us to find what we‚Äôre looking for.

Our driver took us into the tea factory for a free tour. Our guide was exceptionally pleasant and helpful throughout, and provided no pressure for sales (a rare quality in sri lanka). We went as a couple but the experience can be great for all types. Unfortunately there is one component of the tea factory that is not wheelchair accessible, should you need it. However, the rest of the tour is accessible from what I could tell.

We had a lovely time in the Blue Fields Tea Gardens. They offered a free tour around the tea factory (first opened in the 1920s) which provided a lot of details on how the tea leaves are picked and processed. The tea gardens are behind the factory where you can roam around and interact with the tea pickers. They also have a restaurant where they serve buffet meals and a tea centre where you can taste and buy fresh tea.

What a wonderful experience to visit Blue Field Tea Gardens & Factory. It is considered to be one of the best tea factories in the world. When we reached they gave us a guided tour as to how the tea is prepared in the factory which was very unique and informative. Kids enjoyed the most. After the tour they took us to their restaurant for fresh tea tasting which was so rich in taste. Some of the hot teas were free to taste and some had a price. There is a big shop within the factory where one can buy tea for self or families. Highly recommend and clean place.

I go here very often as a tour guide. The staffs are very kind, they have a factory and you can have a look around to see the tea making process, and very good ladies to explain the process. And then you go for tea center to taste a cup of a dust no.1 tea. Off peak times are normally before 11am or after 3pm.

My father and I stopped in to Blue Fielda Tea Gardens for a guided tour of the factory and to sample the tea that they produce. We were very impressed with Mirshad who was very knowledgable and communicated the process of how the tea was processed. We were able to talk through the factory and got to explore the tea fields as well. After the tour we had a tea tasting of the 2 white teas, 1 green tea and 6 black teas. Beautiful and highly recommend this experience! Victoria and Brett

Good start on the types of tea , production, packaging then to the external tea terraces where you can mingle with the tea pickers. Avoid the around mid day as it can be hot. As usual there is a tea shop for you to you type of tea.
The instructor was really nice with us, she was very helpful, had a lot of information about the factory. Her name is Madara. Thank you so much for this great tour.
We visited here on the way from dambulla to nuwaraeliya. You get the complete tea process explained and at the end they serve you with a lovely cup of tea. All satisfying.

I‚Äôm not sure why, but all of he locals want to take you to one of the more modern plantations. We did blue fields and another. This one was by far the better tour and experience. It was working, with machines processing the leaves etc. There are others with better scenery... but the other one we visited was more like a tourist trap rather than a plantation.

Went here today and was very happy with the tour, the guide, the little cafe and the tea shop. The grounds were lovely, well kept and so colourful. While this is not the biggest tea plantation in Nuwara Elia it is Sri Lankan  owned and well worth the visit. Best of all there was no pressure to buy and no one hovered over you like we have experienced in other places.

I really enjoyed the hour here looking at the tea plantation and then being given a tour through the factory and seeing the process. Also learnt a lot about the types of tea produced in Sri Lanka and bought some tasty Orange Pekoe(OP) as a souvenir.

Visited this tea field yesterday. I had a free tour by someone called zaid Who was really friendly. He took me round the factory and showed me the 7 processes involved in making tea! I can‚Äôt believe so much goes into making tea. Also went to the tea fields which were beautiful. It was raining when I went but still amazing. Also got a picture of Tamil tea picker, they do not earn much so if you take a pic with them do give them a tip! My tour guide also took some photos for me so I tipped him too. After the tour we can have a free cup of tea, then we are shown into the shop where we can buy tea ourselves in the purest form. However I didn‚Äôt buy any as I didn‚Äôt have enough money with me, it was a little pricy. Would recommend people going to this tea plantation/ factory.

Our driver brought us here and glad he did. You get a complimentary tour and a cup of tea. The tour was informative and I learned a lot about tea that I did not know. I‚Äôm a coffee drinker. The gift shop was nice with the best tea selection I saw in Sri Lanka. I passed up on getting the Blue Moon blend, thinking I would find it later on. I never found it!! It was one of the best smelling blends I have ever smelled and tea really isn‚Äôt my thing. I‚Äôm bummed I passed it up.

We did not take the free garden/factory tour but we shopped at the tea store. It was very well attended by tourists, and the parking lot was quite full.  Attendants advised and helped people buy tea. We were surprised that the cashier refused to take credit cards without giving us a reason.  Perhaps the phone lines were unreliable due to the rains, but in any event we had to reduce the number of items and pay cash for our purchase. They have a good variety of teas, and the prices were competitive.

Our tour guide, Razar, was enthusiastic and knowledgeable! The factory was actually in operation when we visited so we could the machinery in action. Highly recommend - tea shop had reasonably priced teas and the tour comes with a complimentary cup of English breakfast tea. This was one of the highlights of the trip.

We visited this factory located in beautiful hilly surroundings ,with manually operated machines in a 100 years old building and came out impressed with its focus on giving large employment to locals.They only process black tea here.The guide was a knowledgeable fellow,an employee of the factory. The tour was completed with a complimentary cup of tea offered in the cafe located beside the factory.The cafe is a bare minimum joint,having select food items. An adjoining factory shop was selling all kinds of tea processed by the company.They had all kinds of varieties of tea,some gift packed too. We purchased 200 grams boxes of masala chai flavored black tea at SriLankan Rupees 1600 each,which was expensive compared to buying beautifully packed 40 pcs Dilmah tea bags at Odel, Colombo for SLR 1100. Dilmah being a premium brand is a better gifting option at this price range. Most of the tea factory and estates follow the same business practice,and I would suggest to check other brands tea prices at local superstores before buying from these factory shops-they charge a premium for their teas.

It was good to learn how much of work goes into that cup of tea you drink. Mohammed was our guide for the day and explained every bit of the process in detail.   We were even given the opportunity to pluck some tea leaves. The whole tour was free including nice cup of tea at the end of it. You can buy cakes with your tea. And then your taken to a shop where you can purchase the different types of tea leaves and tea powders. They even have a restaurant there with traditional srilankan food
It‚Äôs been an interesting tour. Doesn‚Äôt take much time. The guide was proffesional and nice. We‚Äôve visited several factories while in Sri Lanka and we found this one to have the best tea shop.

Came here in April with my partner and our three youngest children.  Our guide was very friendly and knowledgeable and explained everything within the factory, giving a clear explanation of how the different teas were made and explaining each stage of production.  We were allowed to take photos and we were also encouraged to help on the production line (which the children really enjoyed).  At the end of the tour you are served with a cup of tea and you can have a browse in the tea shop (but you do not feel under pressure to buy anything - we did not make any purchases).

Very friendly guides who will show you around the factory and serve you with hot piping black tea. All of this is free and no cost. You can choose to buy tea from their store, but no compulsions. A must try place.
We really enjoyed the tour to this tea factory.  Very informative and a great experience for the whole family.

We were taken on a quick tour by one of the tour guides (unfortunately I don‚Äôt remember her name), she explained us all we needed to know about the tea factory. Showing the tea fields to the visitors was not a part of their tour which needs to be added. We overheard some other visitors asking about the tea fields because it‚Äôs quite hot in the factory (obviously) and most of the people visit this place to see the factory and the tea fields both. Overall it was nice, it was a free tour but it‚Äôs nice to give a tip to the tour guide.

We got a tour by Razaq. Friendly man who gave us a very good and clear explanation of the working process of producing tea. Afterwards we could taste the tea and buy some in the shop. Prices were very ok (paid around 500-600Rs for 200-250gr). There is no entry fee but tips are always accepted.

Enjoyed our visit here and the tour of the process we received. The gift shop is extensive and allows you to get your gifts for your return home. The staff are warm and welcoming and the cafe very good. A nice place to visit.

Maybe we just ran into a bad guide, but this was very uninspiring. I think even a audio cassette could impress me more. Also, when taking a look at the tea garden.. You get swamped by old ladies asking for money (for a picture) and not willing you to take any pictures without them on it. Really looked forward to see this interesting site but it all resulted in pretty much a deception. To improve: get those ladies out of the garden and organize paid tours and make it worth the money.

Worthwhile visiting.  Variety of tea leaves.  The whole process of tea making is marvellous, efficient and perfectly carried out.  Our guide Ms. Prasadi is one of the best guides they can ever hire.  She was so genuine, polite, respectful and her explanation was crystal clear.  The tea gift shop is excellent.  The tea plantation view is wonderful.

On our way from Kandy, we dropped by Bluefields. Upon reaching the estate we went to the tea fields behind the factory, where the tea pickers were working. P.S: You will find  tea pickers requesting for a a photograph/video & then asking for donation. Paying them is an individual choice & is not compulsory. At the tea factory we were greeted by our guide, Dinusha Maduwanthi. She was superb at her job! She took us around the factory, while giving us an insight to the tea making process. Dinusha then walked us through the plantations. For city dwellers like ourselves, this was a totally  different experience! Post the tour, visitors are treated to free tea. P. S. only the black tea is free. I tried the Silvertips Tea, which they refer to as "White Tea". Unfortunately it didn't taste any different, from regular tea & was not worth LKR 180. Otherwise our visit at Bluefields was lovely! Entry Fee: Nil Best time to visit: Morning - as you get a chance to see the tea pickers work P. S. Wear sport shoes

Efficient quick and painless. Quick overview of the process, the mearly 100 years old processing machines are impressive and still operate well. It is a co-operative mainly producing white label for big brands. Simple plain experience. In case you are a serious tea person select another estate.

First appearances are that the site is a bit tired looking but we were greeted by our guide called Razar. He was obviously very passionate about the factory and how it‚Äôs still running unchanged since it was first opened nearly 100 years ago. He took us through the full process of how tea is made from the plucking to the fermentation and end product. There are better tea factories to visit in the area but our driver recommended it to us on our way to our next destination. A nice enough stop off for a free cuppa...we‚Äôll nearly free üòÄ

Stopped off here on our way from Kandy to Ella. We arrived on a Sunday when the factory wasn't active but still got an informative, free tour from a very helpful guide (tip recommended). After the tour we received a free cup on Blue Field tea, and bought some cake to go with it. At no point were we pressured into buying anything, but decided to pick up some tea from their shop, which we thought was quite good value. After our tea and cakes, we wandered around the tea fields behind the factory, where we were again provided with a free guided walk by one of the tea pickers. A nice experience, and worth a visit.

Our driver recommend a stop here over the other tea plantations, and for what it was worth, he made a good choice. Unfortunately for us, we visited the tea factory on the weekend of "poga" which is a buddhist/hindu holiday so the factory was not functional that weekend. However, our guide was extremely knowledgeable and informative, who took time to understand and answer any questions we had about the tea and the tea making process. The tour then ended by us being offered a cup of tea for free to try - any cake/pastry purchase is optional and at no point did our guide try to make a sale. The tea shop beside the restaurant was being mobbed by everyone who visited and us as well. Now that we are home and i've tried their teas, I can definitely say that the tea tastes divine. Do stop by to learn and sample a cuppa.

We dropped into Bluefield tea gardens on our way to Ella from Kandy. We ended up having lunch at their buffet - I think it was towards the end of their service, so some of the dishes may have suffered a little from being out for a while. It was adequate but certainly nothing to write home about. It was free for our driver. We got an informative tour of the tea factory and learnt a lot from our very informative guide Razaq.
