I kind of did not realise green tea was just a different harvested leaf from which black tea was from. In their tea cafe we tied their most prized type of tea - a white tea called ‚Äògolden tips‚Äô - I had never had this before but it is from the very young leaf buds of the the tea tree. It was so good we ended up buying 4 tins in their shop to take home with us! A new taste experience which we were excited about. The factory is one of the more traditional types and well worth the visit.

Had a very quick look and tour around the factory. The guides generally say it's free but they say a donation of 500-1000 is standard. You also get a free cup of tea afterwards, and wander around the plantations. Interesting history and they explain really well how the different teas are made. Would recommend if you are going through.

We made a pit stop to the Blue Field Tea Gardens on our way to Kandy. Our guide Adhil gave us a quick, yet detailed tour of the factory and explained the intricate tea making process. We got to taste the different varieties of delicious tea and explore the gift shop. Definitely recommend!

if you are close or are driving from north to south, do not miss the chance to stop there. the guide will take you through the entire tea making process in the factory in a short time and you will try great tastes. very unique experience
We had a lovely tour around the plantation and factory. Very educational and we purchased some of the expensive tea because it seemed very nice quality and all hand made.

It was great to learn about the tea plantations in Sri Lanka. Your staff are very knowledgeable and friendly. Muhammad answered all of our questions. You have a great range of teas for a good price at your gift shop and I loved exploring the factory and seeing how the tea is processed. Thank you
The visit to the tea factory is very artificial, the demonstrator didn't had any passion, he was also not aware of many things that we asked him.
Great tour around the tea factory - very interesting.  Afternoon tea was served and tasty cakes!!  We bought several packets of tea to bring home.
This is one of the best brand. They show us how the Tea is manufactured.  We can buy tea ...we are given tea for tasting also. OPA is the best....

We were taken here by our driver as it seemed he had adequate experience with this area of Sri Lanka. We were given a complimentary tour (however we saw it only right to tip the guide) during which we picked leaves from the fields, went through the factory and production of all three types of tea and finally tasted a complicated cup which was very nice. The shop attached seemed slightly expensive however it seemed in this situation you paid for quality. One thing to note is it is a bit of a tourist trap with a lot of tour groups stopping here and our guide even admitted a lot of the pickers salary came from tourists.
Nice factory with very friendly staff. Short introduction about the tea process and small tea tasting at the end. Recommended.

We stopped here on a tuk tuk tour out of Nuwara Eliya. The tour of the tea factory was very good showing all the stages of the processes to make tea. The chap was very knowledgeable and answered all of our questions. We then were shown to the tea room and given a complementary cup of BOP tea. There is cake also on offer. The shop was rammed with chinese tourists buying up loads of tea. Funny to see as you would almost think they can‚Äôt get it there! You have to pay extra to do a tea tasting. Toilets were clean.
would visit if in the area and after a genuine / old school experience. there are other factories in the area too

We stopped on our way to the Forest View Lodge at the Bluefield tea gardens.The Factory staff was courteous,informative and helped the members of our group to understand how tea is processed.The Tea pluckers pose with tourists.They earn a meager salary for many hours of hard work. The Tea was good quality.The staff at the sales outlet was knowledgeable and promoted the value of tea as a health drink.They have good PR skills..The best quality tea is out of this world

We came across this beautiful tea plantation on our way to Kandy. We were walking to the entrance and were instantly greeted by a friendly tour guide, Mursheey. This was very different to our experience at Damro Tea, where we were waiting for about 20-30 minutes with no one acknowledging that we were there or anyone offering a guide. The tours here are free and the guides will take you around the whole factory providing information about the tea making process as well as history of the plantation. It was great! There was plenty of opportunities for photos and to ask questions. At the end of the tour, you are given a free black tea. There is no obligation to tip or pay any fee, we decided to tip our tour guide as he was excellent :) would definitely recommend this visit as part of your trip in Nuwara Eliya if you get an opportunity :)

Bluefield Tea Gardens is situated at approximately 1200 m above Sea Level in the town of RAMBODA.And it is surrounded by quite and scenically environment. We are warmly welcome you to visit our place on your way to Nuwara Eliya.We are 66 Km from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya main road.

This area is very clean. They provide a free tour how tea is manufactured. There is also a shop where you will find different kinds of teas. It can be tour of one to two hours mostly but do try the tea at the shop. It's one the of biggest tea supplier in Sri Lanka and I totally enjoyed the view, taste and beautiful landscape there
Too many tourists, free tour is informative , geared towards selling tea after free tour. Caf√© was okay. All staff quite friendly

The factory was not operating when we visited as it was a holiday. The guide gave a good explanation of the process. You did not seem to be able to wander through the plantation. There was a children‚Äôs play area. The tea seemed rather expensive so we did not buy any although there were many different grades available. We had a cup of tea but it was not served in a pot and was rather too strong for our taste. There are cakes available to buy at the counter too.
We had a quick..simple...complete explanation of the tour....nice shop with a variety of tea.. .hot tea to sip for guests...fun time.

Nice tour of the tea processing facility with a knowledgeable guide who spoke very good English. Not so impressed with the way the guide said we could/should tip her afterwards then walked away as soon as she got some money. The free tea was not as good as I expected from a tea plantation, seemed to have been brewed too long. The shop was good - every kind of tea and no pressure to buy anything.
We had a tour of this tea factory and it was so interesting to see all the process the tea goes through to give us a good brew. The shop is good and has reasonably priced tea to take home

Had about a 20 minute private tour around the tea factory where you get to see how tea goes from the plants in the plantations to the tea you drink - was great to see all the old machinery still being used as well. The lady that showed us round was very nice, spoke slow and very pronounced English which was easy to understand. I‚Äôm never sure how this kind of thing works regarding payment as it was part of the tour. I gave a 500 tip which seems fair to me, she seemed happy enough. We also got a free cup of tea each at the end, you can order more of different types but the one just to try was enough for us.

We came here instead of Mackwood (now rebranded) and had a fabulous time. Met by a guide, Adil, who showed us around the plantation and explained the process. We watched pickers, took loads of photos and were impressed by the scale and organisation of the place. Back in the factory, they let us gets hands on with loading of leaves into the various hoppers. If you take a pic of a person working, please do remember to give them some rupees, it‚Äôs only polite - 50 should do it! Loved the processing plant and tea sampling - came away from the shop with various ones to try at home. All in it took about 90 minutes and was not expensive. We tipped our guide 500 which our driver said was the going rate. Too Tip: Go early morning before the school tours come!

The best part is that they do not pester you to buy products from their store and all the while give you proper attention while giving a tour of the factory. The tour is short but detailed enough to know the nitty-gritty of the tea process.

It was very interesting and nice to see the when the factory was running. The "tour" was a bit too short and rushed (like 5 min). Our guide was nice but it sounded like a recorded text from a book. After the tour you get a free cup of tea. It's a nice visit of you stop by on the way but it's not worth a daytrip.

Stopped here on our way to Nuwara Eliya. Unfortunately for us it was a national holiday so there was no tea picking going on. We had a tour of the factory though which was still interesting and a cuppa in the cafe. Should really have gone back the following week when it was a normal working day as I imagine there would be more to see. The tour is free and the cafe is cheap. Should have bought more tea as well as it is so good and so much cheaper than home.

we were offered a place on a tour as soon as we arrived. Our guide spoke in English and had a Chinese couple and Japanese couple in addition to us. He was very knowledgeable and spoke very clearly. Tour was 15 minutes and then we went into the cafe for a nice & cheap cup of tea from the various selections on offer. Then there is a tea shop to buy your choice of teas if you wish. No pressure to buy anything. An enjoyable break on the journey to Nuwara Eliya.

Interesting visit to a tea factory. I drink so much of the stuff that it‚Äôs nice to see how it‚Äôs produced. We saw the whole process and then were treated to a cuppa. As we drove away we saw the women working in the plantations. It was very interesting and a good photo opportunity.
I wasn't that keen but it actually was really interesting to see how it all works! We enjoyed tea and samosa afterwards. There's a great shop but no pressure to buy anything

The Blue Field Tea Garden cum Factory was establish in 1921 here we see the procedure of manufacture of tea in factory. We see various kind of tea and test one of them after we go to their outlet and purchase some Srilankan tea. The cost of tea was just double with Indian tea but the cost in Indian currency is near about same.

Stopped here on a tour of tea country and had a nice tour of the factory.  Saw all the old machines, some almost 100 years old and still working.  After the tour, went to the tasting room and had a nice BOP (gotta come here to learn what that is).  I'm not a tea drinker, but I could be one if all the tea was good.  No pressure to buy tea at the shop, they just left us on our own.  I like that!

It was an unforgettable experience, we learned very interesting information about the tea production process, the lady who was guiding us was very polite and informative, she made sure that everything we see in the factory is well explained and understood.
Interesting tea factory with lots of old tea sorting machines. Good tea shop with spectacular views.

This is on the way from Kandy to Newura Eliya and is a good place to stop over not only to stretch legs but also to learn during the stop over. We got a good insight into how the tea is produced and knowledge regarding different types of tea. It has a coffee shop where you get complimentary tea. There is a pastry shop where one can buy pastries. There is a shop where they sell different varieties of tea. No need to go there exclusively to see but can be used as a good stopover.
Take 15 min time to learn about the tea production and sip a cup of fresh tea. Free of charge, while the tea in the shop is definitely overrated. Well, these guys need to get the money somehow...
Nothing exciting about the tea estate. Tea is so highly priced that it is advisable to purchase in Colombo
This place is a must visit on the way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. A quick stop on the way will give you world of knowledge about everything you need to know about Tea.

A good place to learn more about tea production. Every group / couple gets its onw guide who will tell you all about the tea production. Make sure you keep up, as the tour is very fast. Don't mind to ask them to explain again, as they do try to get you in & out within 10 minutes. There is no activity in the factory at Sundays. So it is best to visit an other day of the week. After the (free) tour, you get a free cup of tea. There is also a restaurant if you like. The tea shop has all kinds of tea from this estate. No one was pushing us to buy anything, so you can take the tour and tea for free.

We went on a factory tour here, it's not super busy (when we were there) so it was just us walking around asking our tourist questions. Easy to see the tea growing. A bunch to tea pickers offered for me to take their photo & we quickly learnt that it was for money money money!! The tea is good quality & the factory is worth seeing. Theres also a kids playground so we were able to have a peaceful cup of tea!

Set in a beautiful location, there is no cost attached to the very professionally conducted, informative factory tour that including a cup of tea at the end.  It also appeared to be less crowded than some of the other better known places so we had our guide to ourselves. Her English was excellent and her knowledge vast, from information re the history of the tea growing area, the development of the processing and current marketing strategies. I learned that Dilmah is just another wholesaler like Liptons so no need to pay extra - very important information.  Naturally, we purchased some of their "free-of-additives" tea and it is delicious. If you would like a relaxed hype-free tea plantation tour, this is the place üôÇ

Quite a novelty. See processing of green leaves to Golden Orange Pekoe . Free tea tasting and ex garden sale. Small compared to our Indian tea factories. Interesting for me having insured tea from standing crop to manufacture and auctions.

it was raining but that didn't affect our enjoyment of this place. Mr Siddique was a great guide who talked us through the process of picking the tea leaves to drinking our favourite brew. He answered the questions we have. It was really educational for me and my kids. As a tea drinker, I enjoyed it a lot more.
Visited this tea estate in nuwara eliya. Great location. Brought some tea for friends. Place even has kids play area They served freshly brewed black tea
Good guide worth the stop nice tea and cake.  Makes one appreciate tea more when you realise how hard tea puckers work plus the machine operators doing their bit

The tour was short and did not seem very authentic, the tour was less than half an hour and it did not seem like we saw the whole actual factory. The guide was good. The factory was full with touring cars with big groups of people. There is also a shop and buffet lunch restaurant.

we were thrilled to learn about tea from the history to consumer, however we were guided through the factory in a very expeditive course which lasted no more than 10minutes. we were offered a complementary tea cup at the end and left there "to enjoy"

Same tour offered by all the tea farms, nothing interesting. Drive from NE is long 1h and very winding. I don't think it's authentic factory only made for tourists. In the website they say founded 2017 and in the tour they say 100years old looks more like a tourist attraction.

Very helpful guide was provided and took us round the factory and gave an explanatory the different types and grades of tea. The tour was free. We could take pictures. Some history of the plantation would have been useful, eg some display boards to read. We were taken to the caf√© and could buy tea and we also had tasty chocolate cake. It would have been even better if we could have had a tasting of the different teas, which we could have paid for as an extra. We were able to buy tea from the well presented and stocked shop.

Staff at bluefields were very professional and friendly and we enjoyed having a taste of the tea for no cost and we also purchased some very good quality tea. The toilets however could be a little more improved.
Nice place to learn how to make tea from a leaf. New experience. Beautiful surrounding views. Well English speaking in house guide. Great hospitality with a fresh cup of tea.

We were given a guide to take us around to show the factory. This was free of charge. The guide was very informative and patient with all our questions. At the end of the tour we were offered free tea to taste.

What great, friendly service we received, though we did not have to pay one cent!  Our tour guide was incredibly hospitable and knowledgeable, and the complementary tea at the conclusion of our tour was delicious.  Good quality food in the restaurant, too.  Would highly recommend.

Interesting experience, particularly when our group got to pick tea leaves like the pickers. The tour was excellent followed by the tasting. The downside was being hassled by people wanting to be tipped for everything!

We thoroughly enjoyed our visit, it was very interesting and informative, especially about the different process of making white, green and black teas from the 3 leaves picked from the top of the plant. Lovely cup of free tea, which we followed up with tasting a gold and silver tea. Well worth a visit.

20 minute visit to the working factory. No entry fee just tip to your guide and you have a free cup of tea afterwards and bought extra some nice cakes. Taken photos in the factory allowed. We bought some tea in the shop. It hot really busy around noon when buses with tourists came. You can have a walk to tea plantations just behind factory bulding.

I am a real tea drinker and taking the tour at the Bluefield Tea Gardens with one of their professional guides was ''an education''.   There was so much information to digest about the different types of tea, the processes it went through before arriving at our shops and watching the various machinery process the leaves.  My tea will never taste quite the same again!

Had a guided tour of the plantation and factory and it was quite fascinating and educational to learn how the leaves are picked and then turned into the various types of tea. Well worth a visit and our guide Suria was excellent.

Visited the Bluefield Estate during our trip to the hill country, which is in itself, both beautiful and enchanting.  The tour guides are very knowledgeable and the workers, pleasant and friendly. Most of us drink tea but I suspect that few of us know the picking and production process, so the tour was both informative and interesting. Naturally, we finished up with a cup of the local brew in the adjoining cafe and needless to say, Ceylon tea is very good.
The Tea factory was closed when we visited the place. The restaurant is costly...also the tea shop is very expensive

Well you do learn something but In my opinion it was not a working factory it was an old historic factory. Still interesting and no cost to visit but you make up for it in the shop afterwards. So all in all worth a visit if you are passing by and do end up knowing a lot about Tea, ( although still prefer Morrison‚Äôs Earl Grey ! ) We visited as a couple but good for teens to make a break in the journey Loos and and cafe there as well.

It took us about one and half hour to get there by tuk tuk. It's quite far away. The facilities are a bit old. It depends on your luck if the guide is patient to explain every steps. Our guide went quite fast. After visiting the factory, you can walk around the tea field and have a cup of tea for free. The souvenir shop is nice. There are many varieties of tea and they are nicely packed. They are not cheap though. We found that it's even cheaper to buy tea from shops in Ella.

Liked this place. Had a free ‚Äòno pressure‚Äô 20 minute tour of the factory that was worth a small tip followed by a cup back at the shop. Bought some tea at the shop that even though wasn‚Äôt ‚Äòsupermarket cheap‚Äô it was great quality. This also helps subsidise the tour and free cuppa. It was a Sunday so there was no activity however this didn‚Äôt affect the tour. We were allowed to take photos. Sure this place is a busy stopping point however inside the factory it was a place of calm. The smell of the slightly wilted freshly picked tea in the factory was a highlight.

We got a guided tour with the possibility to pick tea leaves. Very interesting. Nice tea shop and a small cafeteria where we were served tea after the tour. We also had our lunch on the first floor. A small but good buffet. The ladies room was very small so when a larger group of tourists came, there was a queue of ladies all the way out in to the cafeteria. Hopefully the management can improve the facilities for ladies. It would be a much nicer experience to not see such a queue when sipping a lovely cup of tea. The teas that we bought with us from the shop were excellent.

Immediately after arrival we got 10 minutes free walk around factory. There is only black tea production. Tea shop is really good, we visited Mackwoods and Pedro tea plantation and here is not such a big nicely packed variety of tea. Cannot say whether it is overpriced as in local stores we didn't see nothing like these. A bit disappointed about degustation as it is just a one cup of usual tea. Much more worse is a plantation itself as there are lots of poor women and children asking for money and views itself is not best of the best in comparison with others.

We all enjoyed the brief but informative factory tour regarding tea leaf processing. Also enjoyed the tea tastings after this tour and purchased some tea. Lovely setting and all is clean and organised.  A great place to stop in.
The tea factory and its tour is very informative but tea being sold here was expensive in my opinion.

The free factory tour was good - the cafe had good selection of cakes and patties - I like the Veg Puff - Free tea was icing on cake - We bought some green tea as souvenir which is high quality tea. Overall very happy with the visit.
Factory was not in action when we were there, they have a small tea shop and restaurant, Walking through the tea gardens was excellent.

Tea Garden with team factory is an awesome place to visit. The staff there explains every aspect of tea making with right set of detailing. The live demonstration of making white/ black & brown tea is fabulous. Bought couple of different team packs from the shopping store.
The guided tour of tea factory was brief as it seems the main focus is to get you inside the shop to sample the tea and of course get you to buy the tea in their shop.
The tour of the factory itself wansn't that special or long but the variations in tea afterwords was really good. Not too expensive.

One can taste different varieties of teas here in payment basis. There are many types of teas on sale here in different packings. The staff is quite helpful in explaining the difference in varieties. We bought OP & OPA grades. Pl bear in mind that the drivers get a cut, as they bring the customers to the factory.

This factory is few KM before Nuwara Eliya on way. Not that great, when we visited it was closed so couldn‚Äôt get much information about their processes. Got one last to explain us reasonably. It has got one small children park with swings and slides but in poor condition. They have Tea Cafe where they serve one particular type of tea as complimentary and you can buy other types of Tea.
A must visit for tea lovers. Blue field has a wide range of tea flavors to select from. Confirm whether the factory is operational for a better experience.

Lovely young lady gave us a good explanation and tour of the tea process .. though I wish the factory was actually working when we visited.. It was nice to walk through the plantation after the tour. We tipped many of the women labourers we saw as we felt terrible when we learnt how miserably little they are paid for their hard long hours of work. There is small PLAYGROUND which the kids enjoyed after we had our free tea sample and also had some snacks at their coffee shop.  We also bought some tea for gifts.

Upon arrival I was greeted by Muhammed and off we went to the plantation.  Here I had my first introduction to tea leaves and bushes.  The factory workers were on breakfast break and it was lovely to see the super clean and tidy century old factory in its glory. The tour ended with a delicious cup of tea (skip the milk and sugar this time to taste authenticity)!!

It's definitely worth dropping off at this tea factory, even if you've been to others. For a start, it's much small - the company only employs about 200 people and the place has a bit of a family feel about it. Second, we could all around the factory and watch tea being processed, which wasn't the case at the other tea factory we tried (we went on a Monday morning and they don't pick on a Sunday, so you've got to make sure they are working in the factory or you get a trip round a silent building). Our guide was friendly and informative and didn't hang around for a tip - in fact, we sought him out to give him a tip and and couldn't find him. And the tea was complimentary.
This place offers a visit to the tea factory to see how tea is produced. Restaurant offers snacks and meals. Friendly staff,

A few coaches parked outside of the factory, as a group of six, we got a private tour of the factory. The lady greeted us gave a good explanation of how it works. It was quite interesting and smell very nice!

Of all the tea factories I've visited on my travels this would probably be my favourite. The actual tour of the factory is extremely informative and the lady explained the entire process of making tea in great detail. We were allowed to take photos of the factory's insides and then given a complimentary cup of tea. After having our free cuppa and free tour we proceeded to the gift shop which wasn't cheap but also wasn't expensive, moderately priced is what I would say best fits it. Finally we were allowed to take a stroll around the plantation completely unassisted which was lovely. The plantation and grounds are beautiful and the fact that we could go where we wanted on our own really made it special. A definitely must do in this tea lovers opinion.

gardens we visited SriLanka in Dec 2017. On our way from Nuwara to Kandy , we visited this beautiful tea garden and tea factory,. The gardens are beautiful but we were a bit disappointed as the tea factory was closed since it was Sunday. We were offered a cup of tea at the end of tour which was very good. I would recommend a visit to this garden on a weekday.
This place is there to please the tourists We wanted milk tea after the excursion, but we had to pay for it

Good tour but we were never taken into the fields. Also an old women who basically jumped in front of the camera and demanded money was pretty off putting, as I‚Äôm happy to pay if I wanted a photo of one of the women working but i didn‚Äôt ask for a mug shot in front of the fermenting block!

I cant compare this place to any other tea factory because i only went to one. The minute you enter you are taken.on a tour of the factory. It was quite obvious that the information provided was scripted. When we asked a couple of questions the guide couldnt give proper answers. The tour ends with a complimentary cup of tea. I was told that this place has more choices of tea in its souveneir shop. The plus point is on our own we decided to  walk to the tea plantation.(not part of the tour)  The view is amazing. Great photo opportunities. The highlight of the visit!

Tea factory looks rather like place for guiding tourists than really working factory. Guide said about the tip for him at the beginning on the tour. Tea shop is recommended as they have tea in different kinds of packages and very reasonable price. If you want to buy tea you may visit the shop only and for the tea factory tour go to other place.

Our group of five was not impressed by this farm.  Having paid Rs1,500 each for a short tour where you could only see the equipment from a distance behind roped-off areas, it was a disappointment after driving 1.0hr from Nuwara Eliya and then 1.0hr back. The 'gift' packet of tea is of such poor quality (tea dust that goes through a strainer), they don't have the pride to put their name to the packets! Ignorant tourists are being herded here in tour buses. An excellent visit is to the Handunagoda Tea plantation factory near Ahangama, where it is free and you walk in the plantation, are served their good Oolong tea with chocolate cake and get up close to the working machinery.

Great to visit as part of the tour, was fascinating to see how the tea is produced and to be shown round the factory. Opportunities to taste tea and have food in the cafe, and buy products in the shop.

We stopped by at this factory on our way to the city of Nuwara Eliya. The place was surrounded with tea plantations and beautiful landscapes. There's a mini a waterfall right above it. Blue Field Tea Gardens is not just a tea factory but they offer more than that. As soon as you arrive, they will provide a tour guide (for free) who will accompany you inside the factory and explain the process of producing a world class tea product. Once the tour is over, they will serve a free cup of tea. They also have cakes, muffins, pastries, & bread for a very reasonable price. Cheap  tea products were also available onsite.

We went to this farm (over dozens of others) based on the personal recommendation of a friend + trip advisor reviews. This was well worth a morning drive out from our accommodation. Nishanthi our guide was very knowledgeable and explained the process answering our questions. At the end of the tour of the factory she guided us to the cafe where hot tea was served and where we even got explanation about the type of tea being served. The restaurant had some very tasty and piping hot snacks as well as yummy cakes and pastries for us to enjoy with our tea all with very attentive, prompt and friendly service. Clean bathrooms manned by attendants was a huge plus. It even has a small playground for children to enjoy. After enjoying the tea and the snacks we bought the many different varieties of reasonably priced tea they sell. Someone was at hand to help us select and explain the different teas that we wanted to buy. To finish off the experience we went for a nice relaxing stroll among the tea plantation enjoying the lovely vistas from high up in the mountains. Thanks blue fields for the lovely experience and many thanks Nishanthi!!!
Our tour guy was fantastic. Her English was exceptional and took the time to answer our questions as we went. Well worth it.
Interesting tour and nice people showing us around. Opportunity to taste teas and of course visit their shop.

On the way from nuwara Eliya to Kandy we visited Bluefield tea gardens. The tea factory situated in a beautiful area, surrounding with green tea plantations, streams, valleys. They invited with hot tasty tea with a friendly smile. We visited the factory with a instructor who explain all the way of tea process and types of tea. That's good but the instructor(guide) explain like audio display. Need little deep explanation. Any how that was a great experiences. They have a store with many verity of teas. Feel little expensive but worth.

We'd been to tea plantations in the past in Malaysia but this offered a free guide, which made the whole thing a lot more interesting. She was very pleasant and gave us a nice insight into the process. There was even a free cuppa at the end. We just gave her a tip for her troubles.

Stopped here on the road from Kandy to Nuwara Eilya and had a tour this only lasts about 15-20mins and it's free although we tipped the lady who took us round a small amount. Interesting to see the tea making process and to learn about the different types of tea, we purchased some ta after the tour but there was no pressure to buy anything. At the end of the tour they give you a free cuppa which is a nice touch.
Good tea available, can buy various Blueiled tea products, may watch Bluefield Factory for tea making process, can enjoy the scenic view;

Its a nice visit to do. The guide was friendly and showed us the tea plantation and afterwarfs showed us all the process to manufacture the tea. Afterwars they invite us to a cup of tea that was very good.

We are a german couple, visiting Sri Lanka as we met Mr. Indika Dissanayaka on the beach near our hotel Pandanus Beach Resort & Spa. He is speaking german really excellent, so we decided to go on a tour to Udawalawe Nationalpark. But I don`t like to travel with a lot of other guests, because if we could take this guided tour on ourselves, we can stop where we want, stay as long as we want :-). Mr. Indika Dissanayaka arranged an extraordinary tour for us, with taxi transfer, guided tour through Udawalawe Nationalpark with orphaned Elefants Residence and after all a short visit in Fort Galle. This has been an exciting, interesting tour with a lot of comfort (the Taxidriver understands German Language) because we could pause and stop at the interesting places as we want. Thanks a lot, I`ll tell all my friends to get this tour via I.D.Tours Mr. Indika Dissanayaka
Perfect stop for a break on your way to Nuwara Eliya. Great cup of tea and nice cake. Try their chocolate cake.
The title says it all.  The free tour was basic but interesting and the follow up free pot of tea was to die for
tea gardens surrounding with hills....absolutely amazing view. tea was nice as well. this is a must stop place on the way to Nuawara Eliya

A great place to explore and see how Sri Lanka produces their world famous tea.. You can take guided tours at no cost but I can guarantee you will purchase something from their well fitted out shop on site. Great little cafe with amazing views of the area. Well worth the stop to experience and take some great photos.. The tea brings it all back when you arrive home..
I think it is worth visiting of its on your way ,you get to see the process of making tea which is interesting , you can also enjoy the beauty of nature since the factory is between mountains

Visit to bluefield tea garden was a great experience ! On arrival we got Nishanti taking us on a tour of the tea factory. Her clear explanation of tea - White, black and green tea making made it so clear as to why some tea brews light, some strong. My daughter said ‚ÄúI never knew this !‚Äù - At the end of the tour and insisted we buy some tea to take back. The factory had distinct aroma of tea leaves being dried and roasted - did not smell damp despite the rain ! Must visit and buy !

Amazing to see a 95 year old machins still on function and working perfectly- great ingenering success! Mainly black tea factory with a nicly added touch. A bit cold at night time (up in the maountains) get dressed accordingly.
Large factory in operation which fully explains the process of tea making. There is also a shop for tea sales( expensive) and a caf√© to try the tea

I stopped off here on the advice of my driver on my way out of Nuwaru Eliya. It is set amongst an expanse of tea fields (which is useful!) and they provide a free tour around the factory. I went on a Sunday so the factory wasn't processing but it was very interesting to walk around and learn about how tea is processed from being picked all the way to being bagged up for auction. It's simple and educational, at the end of the day it's a working factory and you're learning about how it works. It's followed by a cup of tea (and cake if you like) in the cafe, and you can walk through to the shop and buy tea at their factory prices. There are staff in the shop (who do the tours) who will talk you through the differences of the types of tea leaves and how best to drink them. I was there about an hour for the whole thing. The getting to and from the factory will probably take most of your time but it's a nice site to visit and learn about Sri Lanka's tea production and export.

A visit to the factory is short and has little to no action taking place. Just a detail of the process minus seeing too much happening..... for me that was a downer. The sales centre is well stocked but no deals here , which was also disappointing. One does get a feel of what tea is all about, however.

This was a stop on our way to Nuwara and after seeing all the beatifull tea plantations we learned about making tea process. The lady spoke a good english and was very nice, we tipped her 300 rp. We also enjoyed a tea and bought some for home.

This is a scheduled stop for many tourist operators. The officials explain the process very well.They have a very good restaurant with decent spread and obviously a sales counter to promote the tea sales

Once you arrived this Bluefield Tea Garden, you will be assigned a guide for free. They will explain to you the process of tea making. An eye opening experience and place to learn about green, white and black teas!. Souvenir Shop selling tea as well. But slightly expensive.

Bluefield is the first major tea factory that you would come across while traveling from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. There are good well informed guides who take you around the factory and explain the tea making process and the various kinds and quality of tea. It's customary to offer a small tip. They offer a free cup of tea at the end and it's optional to purchase any sweet or savory accompaniments. There is also a tea shop with fancy packaging. You could walk into the plantations at leisure without a fee.
We hade good experience how to make good tea i like green tea and white tea They offer free guide good staff
This is a nice place to visit.  The tour is short.  The staff are friendly and very helpful.  And most importantly, no one is trying to pressure you to buy anything. The tea is also good.

This is our First visit to a Tea Plantation, it was High up in the Mountains in a most spectacular setting, our tour around the factory albeit brief was very informative and interesting, but be aware that as soon as you get your camera out the plantation staff will soon pop-up wanting money to be in your pictures! After our tour we was taken to the Teas Shop to sample the tea and was given an opportunity to buy some tea, this wasn't expensive nor was there a hard sell. A lovely trip!

Stopped at Bluefield Tea gardens for a free 15 minute tour on our way to Ella. Very informative guide  and afterwards given a excellent cup of black tea. Cake or biscuits are extra and were reasonably priced so we indulged. We are now drinking a pot of tea very day which is so much better for us. Best cuppa.

I have been three tea factory's in nuwaraellia this is the worst factory, just they are trying to sell you some tea that is the main target of them so go some where else don't waste your time and  money there

Here we got nice experience of how tea is produced. Explanation was given point to point in a very nice way. Staff of the factory is very helpful in explaining the process of tea. Along with explanation we got a chance to taste nice cup of tea. First time I got to know that there is white tea as well along with black tea. If time permits then this tea factory is worth a visit. We bought tea packs, our relatives liked it very much üòä
I went there on a day trip and the place is good to see the process that goes into making tea and also to walk around the plantation for some time.

It was busy the day we went as it was the weekend. If you go on a Sunday you don't see the factory working but there is no noise of machinery. You get a free tour which is really interesting and then you are shown back to the cafe for a free cup of strong tea! The toilets are ok. The shop is quite small and a bit pricey. No pressure though. The shop at the St Clair's plantation (Mlesna Tea Castle) is way better, bigger and better staffed. Worth going to both.

Bluefield is the first tea plantation we have ever visited. They offer a free guided tour and tea degustation. The guide shows the factory and explains everything about tea. You can also visit their shop and purchase some tea. Prices are OK.

Visited the factory and was given a tour with explanation on the tea making process. Later on we were given a chance to have free tea tasting.The cafe that served the tea had a nice viewing area. Only minus point, felt the tea pricing was a bit steep. But then they don't force u to buy the products.
We had a tour at the factory. The nice gentlemen showed us how they make tea. It is nice to hear. After that we were offered a cup of tea. The tea was good.

We were given a tour of the tea factory by a friendly guide. Very impressive and noted the aged nature of much of the machinery. There was no pressure to buy stuff from the adjoining shop and caf√©. Definitely worth a visit

Bluefield Tea Gardens is a beautiful tea plantation that to visit while in Ramboda or Nuwar Eliya area. The staff are very friendly and the tour is informative on the process of making tea. I wished that the tour was a bit longer and more detailed but to accommodate the large amount of people I think it's a bit difficult for them. The factory is clean and let me walk around to the back to get some pictures of the tea plantations and the workers. We arrived at the end of the work day (make sure to manage to go ahead of time to see all machines in operation) so we missed some of the machines however, we got the chance to talk to some of the workers before they checked out. The quality of the tea from this garden was some of the best we bought in all of Sri Lanka. I def recommend to buy your gifts and as much tea options as you can. Once you arrive, you also get the chance to sample the tea and enjoy some desserts (rather dry but good enough). Tips: - Arrive early so you get the chance to see everything in process. I believe the work day ends at 4pm. - Tip some of the workers if you can as working in the tea fields is one of the lowest paid jobs in Sri Lanka. - Sample and buy tea!

Nice tour ... an eye opener , it explains a lot about the tea we drink . The gift shop is loaded with all sorts of different high quality tea to take back home either for your own consumption or as gifts to your loved ones. I personally recommend The Blue Moon tea , the smell and taste is simply amazing.
We stopped at Blue Field for tea. Enjoyed a nice chocolate cake. Great cup of tea. Nice restaurant upstairs but we didnt stop for lunch

We stopped at these gardens to obtain a visit, we had our own guide, the visit of the factory took about 15 minutes. Afterwards we had a free cup of tea in the restaurant. They have a shop when you like to buy tea, as coffee drinkers we don't know if prices are high. We also had a small lunch which was nice.

We went to the tea factory there and one of the staff took us to the factory and explained how we get our cuppa to our table! Sadly they were not working on Sunday but we could see the machinery and the rest and also have a cuppa after the little tour. Interesting and informative to my 10 year old.

The guided tour to team factory was very good and guide was very informative and explained the whole process patiently. The factory is very clean and allows visitors to view the process from up close. The tea shop was also very good and offered a wide range of products. Nice place to buy some premium tea. Use this opportunity to buy good tea as the tea sold in these factories is not available outside. Though ordinary tea in Nuruwa eliya etc. shops are cheaper, the quality here is far better and hence worth the cost.
We really enjoyed our tour at the Bluefield tea gardens. Our tour guide gave a thorough explanation of what happens at the factory and we were offered a free cup of tea at the end of the tour.

Very clean and professional tea factory with a friendly and informative tour guide to show you around.  After the tour, a courtesy cup of tea in the lounge.  Of course, they have a shop so you can buy gifts and stock up, which we did.  Unfortunately I managed to forget and leave belongings behind on a couch in the lounge...  Their customer service was impressive - they found my belongings before I even realized I had lost them, put them safely aside, and then sent them on to me by courier.  Could not have asked for more - thank you to staff and management at Blue Field Tea Gardens!!

The factory tour was good and the process was explained well. As we went on a Sunday, we missed out on the opportunity to the see the machines running. The tea shop had many varities of tea but the pricing was high. Tourist factor.

A good way to see how tea is processed. Was met by an English speaking guide (tip only payment) he took us though the factory and explained the process of how tea is made. We then got a free cup of tea, and then left to browse the shop, which was reasonable price.

I have not visited a tea factory for years and was a bit skeptical about what I was going to see and learn. I have never been so wrong. In my early days there was no such thing as tea bags, and i thought tea bags was for grounded twigs! Now i know ground tea can give different strengths. The factory was so clean and the tour was excellent. Shop was very good. We bought some tea to take home. Best part of my story was we left a jacket/coat there and were miles away before we realised this. We gave them a call, and they were so helpful. They sent us a picture to confirm, and then sent the jacket to their store in Colombo, for us to collect before leaving Sri Lanka. Thank you, Mr. Irshad, you showed us not just how good Blue Field Tea Gardens is, but how helpful and kind Sri Lankan people are.
came to Bluefield tea factory twice in 3 months due to the introducing of friend! loving tea dust no. 1, the only choice of cleyon tea.

Walking around the factory by ourselves was interesting  - its a very simple process and we enjoyed seeing it for ourselves. The best part for us was wandering around the plantation - stunning views. Some of the workers approached wanting their photo taken / wanting money and this did get a little wearing but it didnt detract from a lovely afternoons visit. The tea in the shop is soooo pricey - not sure why you would buy it from here. The cafe serves tea and cake - great place to try a cup of different flavoured tea.
Our driver took us here as he said the Tea was good. It was merely a tea shop. Very busy and crowded, more expensive than the other tea factories. Not worth the price or the effort to visit.

We came here having already visited the Labookellie tea factory, and I preferred the Labookellie tour to Bluefield - it just seemed a bit more polished. That said, Bluefield is still good for a run-down of the tea-making process. We also had lunch here, which was 990 rupees/person for a buffet. The food was lovely, particularly the eggplant curry. We also saved our shopping for Bluefield as our hotel owner had told us it was cheaper, and we weren't disappointed. Beautiful 150g decorated canisters of tea were 800-950 rupees, and there was a huge range. On the whole, Bluefield was a great place to finish a day trip through the tea fields.

Probably the best tea tour and factory experience you'll find in Sri Lanka. Friendly guides, interesting tour, and - of course - great tea. If you're looking for a place to visit to lean more about tea in Sri Lanka, then this is the place to go!

I really, really enjoyed the Bluefield Tea Garden's factory tour.  Make sure you take the time and do this because you will appreciate the tea and the process involved so much more.  The plantations are free to wander (so lovely, although if you visited in the heat of the day like me you're wander will be brief) and there is a cafe and retail store.  I didn't sample at the cafe however I did bring home three boxes of different teas to enjoy at home.  For those coming back to Australia, I ensured I bought fully sealed bags and didn't have any issues with customs upon arriving in Perth (make sure you declare them though).  The toilets here aren't the cleanest I will say that, however not to the point you should find somewhere else.  Definitely worth a visit and I'm certainly Enjoying my tea!

We dropped by there on the way back to Negombo. They have a tea production line there. It's a good place to understand the whole black tea diversification and production processes. The guide explained everything clearly. They provided a free cup of tea for every tourist dropping by. And they have a shop there to do some shopping. Next to the shop, there is a quite big play ground for the kids to kill time while parents do shopping. However, the tea there is not cheap comparing with Negombo. Overall, it's a pleasant experience.

We stopped here to buy tea as souvenirs back home to our friends and relatives. The cafe was crowded as it had just finished raining and there was a bus full of tourist awaiting for the rain to stop. As we had finished buying our tea, the crowd had already left with the bus and it was quite peaceful to enjoy a cup of black tea with the tea plantation as the back drop. We didnt mind paying extra for some milk and some cakes as we just enjoyed the hot cup of steaming tea in the post rain weather. Its was a perfect time and place for hot tea. Please do try the free tea, nothing to loose. And if you like it, buy it !
The view of factory was ok. I enjoyed the tea, was definitely good quality, but as is in Sri Lanka, was very over priced.

We stopped by here for a couple of hours on our way to Kandy. The scenery is really stunning!! We had a short tour of the factory (the tea smelled sooooo good), which was informative and free. Of course we tipped! Watching the processes is like travelling back through time to 1921 when the factory was built. Some of the machinery is a hundred years old but still works seamlessly. We then had a free cup of tea and some butter cake, which were both very good. (We also tried the food in the restaurant, which was meh.) We walked in the tea fields for about 30 minutes. Being an amateur photographer, that was probably my favourite part of our visit. The scenery, especially when the weather changes, is very dramatic. Some tea pickers will offer to have their picture taken and then expect some money so if you do want to take photos of people at work, bring some change.

Nice introduction to the processes and steps from harvesting tea up to packaging. 1 of the well known tea estate. Complimentary cup of tea drink and you can shop in the many assortment of teas ready for purchase. Do try to walk pass the factory building to the tea path so that you can have a gorgeous view of the tea plantation valleys and lady workers. Friendly staff.

A should and must visit place on the way to Nuwara Eliya. It's a traditional and old tea factory which is still operational and produced "N" number of flavours of tea. There is a tea tour taken by the staff where they explain about different process of tea making until packing. The tea leaf smell welcomes you which is raw and the final stage of packing gives you best aroma of tea. Post the tour, you are offered hot piping tea which makes you warm in the cold atmosphere. Post sipping it.. you are then guided to buy their best tea which had several flavours. A must visit place which takes approximately 1 hour.

In this tea farm, you can quite easily get a tour.  You just go to the shop counter and somebody will take you on a tour.  The tour is free, but tip I think is expected (we gave a small one anyway).  The tour is just around the factory and is maybe 15 minutes where they explain the production process.  At this farm you can't see the tea plants or do any picking.  The shop has a wide range of teas and I the main restaurant area gives free tea (well we got some free tea after our tour anyway).

They do teach you what the real tea dust means and how it's produced. The way they accept you as a tourist and explains things without reservations is way to learn. Great way and excellent hospitality. Thanks for the tea too...
Good place to understand the tea making process and a quaint little tea shop serving pastries and tea.You may also purchase branded tea from the shop.

They took us through the tea manufacturing process and we were surprised to know the different grades of tea mainly white tea. The tea boxes available in their shops are slightly on the higher side, but the purity is guaranteed. It was raining when we went there and it made the place even more fragrant.

The guide who took us around the bluefield tea factory was a wonderful person.  She explained us all the steps in details, of how the tea is processed.  She also gave us details of the different kind of tea, i.e., black, green and white tea. However, their tea shop is toooooo expensive.  Although my son bought some green tea from there but I would suggest to explore the market first.

Stopped here to see how the tea is processed depending on the type. It was very interesting to learn the process and to actually see it as it is still done today. You even get to have a gratis cuppa before making your way to the shop üëç

It was incredibly informative and very interesting to see the many steps into making the different types of Tea. We arrived and we greeted by a guide (donation payment) who was very well spoken and very informed. There's no action going on at the tea factory but thats because it runs at night. At the end of the tour you get a freshly brewed cup of tea making it totally worth it.

The staff who took us around was very informative and taught us quite a lot about tea production in general, as well as how it is done in Bluefield. He also explained about the various types of tea that are produced here as well as in other plantations, the differences as well as how best to drink them.
Nice place yo visit and learn about tea industry. Worth to drink a coup of tea there and to countinue ur journy...

Go lot of education about tea, how it was made and the procedure goes...there are lot of types of tea's available to purchases at the shop and you can enjoy the free tea that makes there which is very refreshing and very relaxing since it's freshly leaves...I recommend people who loves tea and passing the place to enter, because this is enjoyment

Really nice tour of a tea factory. Not too modernised so you get to see so much more of the process. Great guide who took us through all the different steps. The tea is good too. Well worth stopping here.
Happy to relax a bit on the way to Nuwara Eliya, nice spot we stopped for tea. Need more variety of snacks which suites for foreigners and children.
The tour was very informative with a knowledgeable guide..  They gave us a free cup of tea.. We could understand various steps of tea making and different types of tea.

Wow... what a beautiful area and tea plantation. We got a free tour of the factory from a knowledgeable guide and learned a lot about tea in the process. Afterwards we received a free cup of tea which I complimented with two small slices of a tasty "Butter" and "Fruit" cake. Grand total for the tour, tea and two slices of cake, LKR 360 including a LKR 200 tour guide tip. A "Tea & Souvenir Shop" along with a Cafe is also on the property. However, there was no pressure to make a purchase as Tea Shop is in a separate room from Cafe. Feel free to roam the ground after you are done enjoying your free cup of tea.
One man showed us around the tea factory and we tried some black tea in its shop and bought some there. Love the Ceylon tea!

We visited on a Sunday when the factory was not running, but the tour was still interesting. Our guide was knowledgeable and answered all of our questions very clearly. Lots of options for tea purchase in the shop afterwards.

We went for lunch to the Bluefield Tea Gardens restaurant on our way back from Nuwara Eliya. They had buffet lunch for reasonable price,but unfortunately the quality of food was low. We also took a lime juice which is also not good. Need very much improvement in food and also restaurant area needs some refurbishment and they had no AC.

The location is simply superb and there is ample parking place and after your visit to the tea factory you can relax at the cozy restaurant where you are served complimentary tea . There are many varieties of ceylon tea being sold here which is quite expensive. This place is worth a visit.

For tea factory tour, or to purchase teas, or to have lunch, this place is overall really great. Must visit. The gardens are charming, and what a breath taking view of the mountains and rolling mist. The restaurant is cozy, with good selection of food. I loved the Iced Tea here, one of the best I've had anywhere.

few moments before this on all 4 sides you see Lush Green Tea Plantations. The Blue Fields Tea Factory is Big & you can see more details in the photos attached. The Tea Factory tour is approx 30 mins, where they show u the making & complete process how Ceylon Tea is made !! after the tour they drop you to it's restaurant, check the Blue Fields Restaurant review for this

First of all - it¬¥s free of charge - big plus! You¬¥ll get a guide who explains every step of the tea manufacturing - from collecting leaves to drying & shredding, different tea types etc - quite interesting! After that you can go into the restaurant and have a gratis tea and you can tip your guide - or not, however you like. The whole procedure did take only about 30 minutes, but it was worth the time! Would recommend to anyone near this area.

A guide will show you through the manufacturing stages of the tea.  The tour is less than 30 mins and there's a free brew afterwards.  It's customary to give a small tip and well appreciated. Tea is expensive in all the factories - but it's excellent quality.

A kind lady gave us a tour, she spoke fluent english and showed us from stage 1 all the way to the packaging stage of their tea factory! we then went to the gift shop area for a cuppa free tea and bought some teabags home too. Tour was fairly short though.

This was an excellent choice by our guide As usual in Sri Lanka everyone is friendly and our guide ,a young girl dressed impeccably in a Sari was informative and articulate we learnt a lot about Tea we hadn't known before and then a complimentary cup of tea and cake at the end Totally recommended

Unfortunately they were closed by the time we arrived - don't travel over Sri Lankan New Year (April 13-15) as most people close the factories due to the holidays, however the coffee shop and tea store was open and the guy inside explains the variations of tea. The store was also inexpensive when compared to mackwood (now called browns) so fret spot to buy tea to take back home to family and friends.

This was a good place to experience the tea growing and process.  We were shown around by a knowledgable local guide and her English was excellent.  We tipped her a few hundred rupees at the end.  You can see the basic leaves and how they are turned into different varieties of orange pekoe black tea.  There is a shop where you can by the tea leaves and also you get to try a cup of the basic black tea for free.  Cakes and milk is also available at an extra charge.  Do walk around the gardens too where you can see all of the tea bushes where ladies picks average of.20 kg of tea leaves every day.  We were hassled a bit in the gardens which was annoying by an old lady who wanted us to take her photo for money and also a guy who wanted to 'escort' us around d the gardens for money.  Again we give him a couple of hundred rupees even though his English was terrible and he added no value to our visit whatsoever but he was persistent and I just wanted him to go away!

Nice place to visit for lunch (get stuck in the buffet and you will need an hour to recover after!) The tea factory is still working - the many "no picture" boards are hilarious when the guide tells you to take pictures. A nice tea shop - great view amongst the hill tops. What more does one need.

Yes it is touristic. But not a tourist trap. The girl gave a nice tour which indeed does not take more than 10minutes. But in this time everything was said. So no complaints there. They didn't push us into buying stuff. They gave us tea for free at the end of tge tour and let us be. We had a 2nd tea (paying) and some cake. All at good prices if you ask me. The store itself seems to have acceptable prices as well.

Good place to go if on your way. Don't go out of your way to go there though as not worth a detour. Friendly place that explains the full process of tea making from moment leaves are picked. Good education for a basic product we take for granted and use everyday. Tour of factory and good knowledge by guides. It's a basic free tour . Nothing more to it than that.
A nice little experience that starts from Tea making factory tour. It is situated in the middle of tea estate. The tea is highly expensive.

The tea factory tour was very informative,from picking up the tea leaves till packing... our tour guide was very helpful , he helped us pick up gifts from the shop... and not to forget the tasty tea in the restaurant.

We were taken on a tour of the factory from processing of raw tea leaves to finished product. It was very interesting. All of the loading of tea leaves is done manually by women who I suspect are paid little as is the case with pickers. It is a remarkably and surprisingly labour intensive process. I don't think I will drink a cup of tea again without thinking of the workers I saw labouring away. Anyway, so much for my left leaning tendencies - one would hope fair trade might occur as it has in the coffee trade. Well worth a visit, and the tea on sale is quite cheap.
On the way to nuwara eliya. Best place for lunch. Lots of food items and standard menus. I enjoyed the meals a lot. Thank you for my driver to stop on the correct place
a quick tour through the factory to understand how tea is made, then off to the tea shop! A bit overpriced, but the tea was lovely, and the tour interesting.
It was a good and informative rest and pit stop. The guided tour included explanations on how the raw tea gets turned into the end product and our guide was knowledgeable enough.

The overall visit was good. And the complimentary black tea was also nice... For those who don't know how tea leaves are processed . But if your an Indian just beware of the old ladies working there. They will ask you to come with them to see estate and ask you money...
We had a guide explain the process of tea growing and processing which was alot more interesting than I thought it would be.  We enjoyed morning tea in the very pleasant cafe.

A trip to Sri Lanka would not be complete without a visit to a Tea Garden. And Bluefield Tea Gardens is a great example of why Sr Lanka tea is most flavorful and sought after by tea lovers the world over. They have great tour of processing of the tea leaves which was very enjoyable. The factory and it's surrounding areas form a great backdrop for pictures. A tea shop with free tea servings are an added attraction. Attractive packaging of tea leaves for sale - at the time we visited - the only drawback was we had to pay with cash - no credit card transactions were accepted - not very convenient for the international traveler.
Blue Field Tea Garden an authentic place to purchase original Sri Lankan tea with different types and taste.
A wonderful place with a great view. They offer good tea here and a variety of teas were available at their shop. They Offer free entry to the tea processing area. The staffs were very friendly

when we travelling to up country we drop to here for a tea it were a lovely experience.good location with a nice view and lovely birds flying in the out side of the tea shop its a awesome.butter cake is good.tea is superb,a bit want to improve of the customer service giving by the waiters.we had to wait more time to coming some one to take our order no one forward to us then we went near to the cashier and gave the order to them.want to improve up customer service overall all good and good luck

There are many tea estates and factories near Nuwara Eliya, but Blue Fields seems to be one that is better set up for visitors.  Informative tours of the 100-year old factory are provided and visitors are allowed wander throughout the tea plantations.  Good opportunities for photos. End the tour with a nice cup of complimentary tea and chance to buy overpriced tea in their shop.  Blue Fields is about 20 kilometers from Nuwara Eliya (farther than many other tea factories), but it's a nicer experience than many others.

we had an enjoyable stop over here. The tour was highly educational with regards the tea process. The complimentary tea was divine and the cakes very tasty and inexpensive. Well worth the stop. I would recommend this.

A slight disappointment in that the guide, just fired us through all this and the plant was not working due to a funeral. Interesting all the same and then you get some bad service at the end in the tearoom to make up for the 10 mins getting shown around. I would not recommend this as we found it to be 'oh I cant be bothered", 'what more tourists", not for us wish we had not bothered.

We went there to take photos of the tea-leaf pickers and visited their factory and shop too. The factory visit was short, but still interesting, picking up some knowledge of the different types of tea. Their shop offers a variety of teas that they produce, all of reasonable prices, nothing that is exorbitant.  I bought the golden tip and silver tip tea leaf.  It is good.
A local friend  organised a tour here and explained that you get to buy your Tea at a fair price We foundd this to be true
Our guide was clear and took us through the entire process. The tour obviously ends at the shop which offers a wide selection of tea.

Majorly women are employed in this factory and mainly manual process is undertaken for producing the tea product. All the tea plucking staff are women. As soon as you reach, staff guides you and explains you the process of tea produce in the factory. Types of tea and the benefits from each tea type is explained very well. Very informative and enthusiastic staff. Complimentary tea is served after the explanation. Natural tea products are available in powder as well as tea bag form. The staff also explains the cost for packaging involved and suggests you the right pack as per your budget. Enjoyed.
Do not drive past this! Short personal walk through the tea making process in the 100 year old factory, from a very personable & interesting guide.  Followed by tea, all at no charge!
Very nice place with lots of ftes firlds around. Simply honoured to take a tour in bluefield. Hope for the best
We really enjoyed the visit, our guide was very pleasant and he spent time with us, he was easy to understand and answered all our questions.

Had a very interesting tour around this tea factory. Our excellent guide explained all about the way the tea is grown, harvested and then produced within the factory. Had a first-rate cup of the tea as the tour finished.
Had a tour by a lovely Sri Lankan girl. Very interesting facts around tea. The place have a decent place yo have tea and pastry and a good shop as well. Beautiful surrounfin6.

Several types of teas are prepared here! A guided tour explains the differences clearly the process of making tea! Tea tasting is possible before you want to buy or choose your favorite tea! The English spoken by guide may not be clear but if you ask question, you get answers! üòÄ

We had a guide with good English and she explained very clearly the processes involved in tea production. Not rushes. Had a nice cup of tea afterwards and bought lots of tea to come home. Countryside round about is lovely.

We were on an organised tour of Sri Lanka and this was one of our scheduled stops. The tour around the factory was very interesting and the old British machinery still is in working condition. The ladies were then encouraged to try picking the tea out in the field for themselves, it was a great laugh watching them working so competitively in the field. Then as a reward, we were all treated to a wonderful cup of tea followed by, as usual a tea store visit.
Nice tea factory, although we did not see it working as it was sunday, it is free too! But the gift shop Probably makes up for it!

Short, crisp and informative tour of the showcase tea processing facility.  The area around the center offers a delightful view of tea gardens interspersed with small brooks and quaint bridges. A winding road takes you up the hill for a birds-eye view of the mesmerizing valley studded with lakes. Inside the outlet, there is plenty to choose from - variety, flavours, quantity, and packaging.  Staff is efficient and helpful. There is a nice cafe where you can sample different kinds of tea and complete the experience with a choice of cake on the side. Wish the owners lay as much importance to the availablity of enough and clean toilets.

Found this place informative and did purchase quite a bit of tea to take back home as well as distribute among friends.  They serve a free cup of black tea per person. I wish they had the option of milk tea and if not liquid milk at least milk powder as I do not fancy black tea. We had lunch here but the lunch buffet was just okay, nothing great. Dessert options were very limited. I was hoping to see more of Srilankan food.
A very good tea factory, offering free tours of the facilities and complimentary cup of tea afterwards.

Good information about the tea plantation...the whole process of how tea is made and the machinery used to process the tea...the people involved in it was explained in detailed...good experience..we bought different varieties of tea from there too..loved it...

Blue field tea factory is located between Kandy - Nuwara Elia road. You can visit the tea facotry on free of change, also you can buy tea and they have a restaurant as well. Most of the foreign and locals visiting this tea facotry.

I stopped here for a break and had tea and cake followed by a free tour of the tea factory.  My guide had a lot of knowledge and took me through the entire tea making process.  It was interesting an informative. She then showed me all of the different teas on sale in the shop and explained why some were much more expensive than others.  The good thing is that you can walk into the tea room and taste the teas before you buy any.  It is not the cheapest place to get a cup of tea but quite unique.

Somehow we did not find a guide, even though most other tourists did walk through the factory with a guide. A worker sent us in on our own, so we explored the factory by ourselves. There was just half a band of fresh tea leaves currently being dried and no worker (or anyone else) was around on that floor, but in the lower floor the rest of the tea processing was happening on a seemingly normal scale. It was indeed interesting to see the individual steps from the leaves up to the various tea types. The tea store was well stocked and overcrowded, with a lot of tourist buses buying huge amounts of tea. Our apartment hosts already recommended us (and were right) only to buy small amounts of tea for presents, as the price was indeed extraordinarily high and the quality the same as you find in normal shops. Afterwards, we ate a little and enjoyed a cup of tea in the Cafe. Overall a nice visit and definitely great to walk a bit among the tea fields that are so common in this area of Sri Lanka.

The tour was short and simple and well done even though we didnt see much in action.  The tea tasting consisted of one tea which was nice but made it difficult to understand the difference between the tea they made and sold...the others are available for a cost but I didnt have space for 5 full cups of tea :) We bought some tea from the wide selection on offer and then afterward went to the local village and found the same tea much cheaper in the shops! The selection was a lot smaller so I am still glad I bought what I did but it was disappointing to feel that they were taking full advantage of the captive market of tourists :(
The tour guide in tea factory is really nice and the explanation of process of tea is clear and helpful. I think the price of the tea is fare.

We had a short tour around here. The girl who showed us the stages of tea production was a fountain of knowledge & was able to answer questions we asked & we learnt some interesting facts. We did buy some tea at the end because it isn't available at home.

I visited on a Sunday. The facory was not operative but one assistant showed us around the factory and showed us the processes involved in making tea. We were also given an explanantion of the different types of tea. Then we were given a cupof tea to drink.Nice visit.
We had a very short visit in the tea plantaion, a longer and interesting visit in the factory. The tea shop had about double prices compared to the normal in shops and hotels.

Informative tour. Unfortunately, we were there on a Sunday, so we didn't get to see the factory "in action." Provided with tea after the tour. Tea Prices very reasonable. Must do when visiting Sri Lanka!
Quaint factory with a short tour where you see the tea being dried and fermented. At the end of the tour you have an opportunity to sample different types of tea and purchase.

We chose to come to this Tea factory because its blue colour looked very beautiful. In fact, even inside the factory, unexpectedly, many parts are in blue too. Nice colour. There is no fee for the tour. A guide explained the tea and differences between different kind of tea. And, showed us around the operation. We visited on Sunday and no one worked and so we could not see the real operation in the factory and tea fields. But, we could walk over to tea fields to take few photos. After the tour, a free tea was given and we could relax a bit. We did some shopping here, though not sure if it was reasonable price or not. But, at least, we took some good photos.
very good quanlity of tea,most important is the price you can't imaging!so maybe the ladies' salary who pick leaves are far low beyond we know,I guess.
We loved this tea factory tour. Very informative & the shop is good at the end and reasonably priced. The cafe is great. We preferred this tea factory over Mackwood's.

The tour lasted for around 10 minutes. We were shown the fresh tea leaf, which was then dehydrated, grounded, fermented and     sorted. The factory had a lovely aroma. The small restaurant served free black tea but milk tea would be charged. The tea was very smooth and had a sweet after taste which lasted for an hour.

It is situated in beautiful Ramboda and has a spectacular view. The tour of the factory is free and their guides are informative and nice. When we went to look at the plants by our selves we were followed by a   young boy and an old lady they kept insisting that we had to give them money and would not leave us alone. This was not the factorys fault but it colored our impression of that day. After we got away from them we went to the little shop where they were most helpful with showing us their different teas and helping in any way they could.

Free to enter, short 15minutes individual guide through the factory by friendly guides of Bluefield factory. Good first impression how tea is being made, informative. Then you receive a cup of tea in the restaurant area (few dessert options to buy if one wants) And there is a tea shop with great selection of locally produced tea. The guides are there to help you, tea samples available. Depends what kind you want, it starts 4usd onwards.
We had just tea, but it was an amazing experience in the hils on a tea estate. Tea was refreshing with many choices

We didn't go for the tour around the tea factory but instead just stopped by on our way back for a cup of tea. There is a cafe that serves very nice tea & cake at a very reasonable price. We ordered the tea with milk & sugar and a slice of chocolate cake. It was so good that we ended up buying the same tea we drank in the cafe from their tea shop. If you prefer your tea with milk & sugar then go for the BOPF and the DUST graded teas. Their tea shop was reasonably priced but cheaper tea can be bought at the Sri Lankan Tea Board in Colombo. There are staff there to help with any questions. There are teas packaged as gifts that can be bought as well. Only negative was the tea cafe was full of flies that we had to keep swatting away from our tea & cake and the toilets in  the cafe were very dirty & unsanitary. However I would recommend Bluefields over Mackwoods tea estate.
Pretty tea field but prices higher than others we visited and full of tour buses when we visited. Easy to get to as on main road to Newara Eliya.

The Bluefield Tea Gardens and factory is a great way to stretch your legs when on the way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. The tour of the factory was informative although very dusty. The cup of tea provided after the tour was lovely. The toilet facilities were very clean. There was food available, but we did not consume any, so cannot inform you of its quality. The price of the tea however was quite high and as such we did not purchase any.

And this was a very good tea garden with a nice guided tour of the tea factory- the tour is free along with a cuppa to sample post tour. Most visitors buy some fresh tea and so did we... not cheap tea but good quality I presume as I have not yet tasted it. Worth a visit.

Unfortunately as we visited on the weekend we couldn't see anything working but we had a really excellent tour and explanation of how everything worked. Afterwards we had a lovely cup of tea and opportunity to buy some local tea.
good experience to see tea processing techniques. Huge variety of flavored and authentic tea. perfect stop over on the way to Nuwara Eliya
We stopped by this tea factory on the way to Kandy from Nuwara Eliya. the way itself is also good worth it. Factory offered free guide and one bottle of tea.

We received a complimentary tour from a very helpful guide (which, after going to a few of these, we learned is definitely not the norm). It was a lovely glimpse into the world of tea production. The tea fields in the immediate vicinity aren't as picture-worthy, though, so head elsewhere for your photo op.

This is a must visit destination for tea lovers. It will take you to the world of produce, lived the location and had a brief from the producers about the 100years old British constructed factory. After that visit the fields and see how the staff are picking leaves and then enjoy free tea (only black).

The man who took us to the factory was very friendly and ready to answer any question. It is nice to see the process of tea. when we finish he took us to taste it in the coffee shop and it was the most amazing tea I have taste. We bought for us and for our friends. The prices in comparison to tea prices in our country are the same.
the visit of the factory is nice and instructive but do not miss the real gem: the tea plantations behind it! You can stroll between the hills, see (and smell) the tea and interact with the workers.
