Wish the tour included a visit to the plantation to see the picking of tea leaves. Would have loved to learn about soil and climate conditions and also see the tea being harvested. Expensive teas in gift shop. Overall disappointing!

Led around the factory by one of the members of staff who was well versed in English,  the process of tea making was one that enthralled. Each machines function was explained in detail,  and we were even treated to a free cup of black tea at the cafe-although milk had to be paid for.   Kids will enjoy the play area outside.

We visited at the wrong time of the day to see all of the tea processes, nonetheless it was still interesting. The Bluefield's guide explained the steps well (politely checking we understood along the way), and was not expecting a top at the end - as is the case everywhere else. At the end of the (short) tour, a complimentary cup of tea was offered. The staff in the shop are not pushy, but assist in making choices.

The plantation is beautiful and we were lucky to have a very nice guide who explained all about their tea production process. They offer you a type of tea for tasting and you can buy different cups of tea in the cafeteria. You will find all types of tea in their shop afterwards, be sure to buy some

The family was overjoyed and we had an excellent female translator well exposed to the end to end process who shared with us the process. She was knowledgeable and very sharp in answering questions especially from both my children who were lawyers. The session to taste the tea at the lobby was heartwarming again. Which followed up with us purchasing a few different types of tea. Well organized, truly professional well laid out.

A nice stop in Nuwara Eliya. You get to visit the factory and each step of tea production is explained. You get a free cup of tea at The end of your tour at the cafe. The cakes are good here and they also serve lunch.

I recently walked trough the Bluefield Tea Factory, accompanied by a guide to explain the process how the tea is made. The tour is short. After the tour you are offered a free cup of  black tea. The factory has a coffee shop that allows one to purchase tea treats such as chocolate cake. On the premises their is a shop where you can purchase the tea. The tea is able in various flavors. The coffee shop and the tea shop is at a reasonable price.

I guess you go to Nuwara Eliya for the train ride to Ella and the tea. We went to Bluefield Tea Gardens for the tea plantation tour, although there are a good many to choose from. You walk in, get served tea, get a 10 minute tour of the tea factory and then get to go to the shop to buy tea. Lots of yummy selection if you are a tea drinker, which i was and am now even more of one now that I have spent time in Sri Lanka feasting on their delicious teas!

The day we visited the factory was closed. The process that was explained to us was lackadaisical. The main push was towards people buying the tea from there. But the tea room was fantastic where they serve you bad tea free of cost.

The tea factory is also a tour factory. Wait 10 minutes because a friendlier, more peaceful and less expensive product is just up the hill around a few bends. Bluefield banks on being the first major tea estate on the road to Nuwara Eliya with a remarkably blue building that is picturesque. The tours are rushed - rusged right into a gift shop. Pictures are prohibited of most of the machinery whereas other estates permit them. Just be patient. more tea is waiting up the hill. You will enjoy the experience more elsewhere.
This is a lovely place to stop off...free tour that explains the entire tea making process. Very informative...followed by a cup of complimentary tea...must try the cakes which are cheap...
Had a good cup of tea while heading back to Colombo. Though it was crowded staff worked tirelessly to give a great service to all customers. Only issue was washrooms was not that clean.

Had an interesting tour with family here recently. The tour opened up our eyes on how tea is manufactured. It was rather interesting and the kids loved the process. Definitely recommend this. We also drank some tasty free tea and was able to shop for fresh tea right in their store.

We were promptly greeted by a smiling Bluefield tour guide upon arrival at the tea factory. Being an avid tea drinker, I along with my family was eager to learn the process of the tea production at the fundamental level from a tea factory. While inside the factory the guide started off by relating the history of the Bluefield tea estate and general overall process of the stages of the step by step production that it undergoes, from the picking of the tea leaves to finally to the point where it is sold at the main auction in Colombo and London. The guide was very accommodating and receptive to our many inquiries, especially my kids who had numerous questions and was awed at the some of the menial tasks required. Most importantly the guide was able to differentiate the quality of the tea that is produced, elevation dependent and provide us with a detailed breakdown of the types and kinds of tea, which is imperative and useful information for the casual tea drinker in order to be able to distinguish fine tea from the not so fine tea. Finally at the conclusion of the tour the guide pointed us in the direction of the tea store and the caf√©, where we informed we can help ourselves to a complimentary cup of tea. While inside the boutiques I approached the tea counter to request a cup of tea and some pastries upon which I a politely told by the counterperson to take a seat in the front lobby and they would bring the items to our table. Promptly our family was served a fabulous cup of tea and some fine pastries to go along with it, the butter cake is fabulous and my favorite was the spicy seeni symbol filled bun. I did also purchased some tea in the boutique as my decision to buy more than I initially planned was influenced by the tea that I consumed at the factory. The boutique is well stocked and does have a broad selection of the types of tea that was covered and explained in our tour earlier. It was an educational and fun experience and I learned quite a bit about tea production from a factory perspective and I am quite certain that I will have a more appreciation and admiration the next time I enjoy my tea.

So we were seated upstairs as we wanted food from their "ala carte" menu.  The waiters gave us the menus to choose from and in 2 minutes snatched it from us and gave the menu to another group.  So we went back to him to.take our orders and we were told that they can't serve at the moment.   As we started making our way down it was disappointing to note that the same waiter was taking order from the menu from another group!  They could not be bothered when confronted as to why are we not being served.  Avoid with a vengeance!

Arrived early in the morning and were offered a tour of the factory. Very informative and our guide was knowledgeable after tour we were given a cup of tea Afterwards visited their shop where there were a teas made by Blufield for sale.  Staff very friendly and helpful. Shop takes credit cards

What I liked about this factory is that the guides are very clear and it is possible to follow the process without having to guess or feeling stupid for asking questions. Having been on a couple of other factories,  this is definitely the best. Also: try the cake at the restaurant.  Not too greasy, not too sweet. Just perfect! We had the coffee cake and the chocolate cake and they were heavenly!

We arrived at Bluefield and were assigned a tour guide who took us through the tea factory explaining the tea manufacturing process. She was very knowledgeable and we learnt a lot about how the different types of teas are made. After the tour we had a tea tasting, where we were able to taste about 8 different tea varieties made by this estate. It was a great experience as you could decide which teas to purchase whilst in Sri Lanka.
Free tour of the working tea factory with a guide - only took 20 minutes but extremely interesting and worthwhile doing, especially on a rainy morning!

Our guide took us here on way to Nuwara Eliya from Kandy. Got a good tour of the tea factory and good educative trip for the children. Shopped for a fair bit of tea as gifts back home at their store.  We visited some shops later in Galle and found the Bluefield Tea prices quite high. Packaging is also better elsewhere for gifts. So good stop but not the best place to buy tea

We arrived the day after Christmas and, understandably, there were no tea pickers and the factory was not operational. This is a common disappointment, so you either plan to come on a good day or expect to miss out on certain aspects of the tea factory tour. We snagged a guide within seconds of asking a manager. The guide gave us a perfunctory tour with superficial explanation of how the factory works. They do these tours dozens of times a day, so don't expect an impassioned treatise on tea with in-depth soliloquies from your guide. This was the first of two major tea estates we visited on this day. Although the machines were not running, we were not allowed to take photos inside (Mackwoods, the other estate we visited, did allow photography inside the factory). The guide dropped us in front of the cafe exactly five minutes after the tour started. His body language indicated that he wanted a tip which, when offered, prompted him to tell us about the free (single-cup) tea tasting at the cafeteria. Don't expect the servers to tell you anything about the tea (we asked and found out that they served BOP - broken orange pekoe, standard black tea). We ordered the Swiss chocolate roll and the coconut cake, both of which were delicious. We didn't feel like they were trying to sell us anything because they didn't drop us off at the store. But the tea store at Bluefield was far, far better stocked compared to Mackwoods during our visit. Mackwoods had only two or three kinds of black tea, whereas Bluefield had dozens of types in different sizes and packages and for different prices...which are quite high, but we loaded up anyway because of the boutique value of the products, which make good souvenirs for loved ones. Overall, the jury is out about which tea estate is better, but despite its more modest tea store, Mackwoods offers better views of the hills and tea plantations around it.
Fabulas green hills and slopes of tea, pickers working away as years gone by. Great guide and very informative, free cup of tea to boot.. Thank you blue fields and sri Lanka what a special country.

The road to Bluefield tea garden is very scenic up and down the hill with full of tea plantations and vegetable farming. A person takes you to the tour and after completing it you are offered a green tea.. there is a shop with all the varieties the produce .
We visited this place after Mackwoods. The tour is more personal and more informative. Afterwards we also enjoyed a cup of tea.
Nice staff very factual, tea in shop rather expensive but felt I should buy some to get fresh stuff straight from source
nothing special about this tea garden, was the same as the rest. we did not have a good guide, we could not understand what he was saying as he was slurring, overall view was nice

I was taken by the pre-arranged guide for a tour of the tea factory. One that day no-one was working due to a national holiday. The tour lasted no more than 10 minutes and just mildly interesting. You are also expected to tip the guide 500 rupees. Then I deposited into the shop selling numerous varieties of expensive tea. There is a cafe where you can buy and drink and food.

One of the few Tea factories, where you can see the Processing of tea live/ demo. The staff person takes you around and explains you the workings and the procedures involved in making different types of tea. At the end of the tour you are expected to tip the guide (they will not pester you for tips though). You even get a free cup of tea for sampling anfd can buy different varieties from the shop there.

The venue is just by the road though Ramboda from Kandy towards Elyia, the mountain recluse built by the British. We saw tea growing everywhere on the slopes of the mountain. The scenery is very, very green. Beautiful if you look over all the rubbish of the villages of this developing country. At tea factory we were welcome by a guide who spoke excellent English that is not common at all in Sri Lanka. She explained to us how rthe tea is produced and all about different qualities of tea. It was fascinating. The only minus point was that we could not see the factory in working as this was the holiday season. The guide had to rush to help other tourists but still she was able to answer all our questions. The free cup of tea at the end of the tour was delicious.
The guide was a very friendly woman with a very good English and excellent explaining. She was not stressful and did no unconvinient pushing for tip or buying from the teashop.

Went there on our way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. Staff member came out to show us around, and gave a very good explanation. We were allowed to take pictures of the various processes involved and feel and smell samples of the tea in its various steps to the final product. At the end we were given a free cup of tea. At no point did we feel pressured to tip or buy anything - although we did get some earl grey anyways! Would recommend.
Good place. Feels old with 100 year old equipment and old way for producing tea powder. Various varieties to choose from. They even have a small play area for kids
Go and visit the factory. It is an interesting short tour with explanations from young ladies. After the tour you can buy tea or have a cup of tea.

The short tour was free with a complimentary cup of tea at the end. You may purchase their tea at reasonable prices. Due to the long journey ahead we had lunch here too - buffet only but no a la carte. The food was below average, unfortunately.

This was my second tea factory tour and equally, I enjoyed and learned about the processing of tea. My lady guide was knowledgeable and answered all my inquiries. To end the tour, I had a delightful cup of tea. I had two types of tea to try. I think I was "all-tead-up" from having at least 4 cups of tea from visiting two factories. The tea plantation view was lovely. So much tea selections to choose from, so just pick the tea that suits your taste and you won't go wrong. The place also have a little bakery where you can purchase and enjoy some pastries while you savor and enjoy your cup of tea.

Bluefield tea gardens are on the way from Nuwara Eliya to Kandy. Its a short tour which takes around 1 hour to completely visit the tea factory . Representatives of the tea factory acts as your guide and they explain the entire process of tea making starting from plucking of the tea leaves to the transformation of the green tea leaves into finished packed tea boxes. They have an entire array of tea leaves and the most expensive tea is the white tea. They serve you a variety of tea which is free of cost and they have a tea outlet which has a huge range of different varieties of Tea . You can buy the tea of your choice by paying in Srilankan rupees. The factory itself is situated in the picturesque surroundings of the lush green mountains and  hills. Overall a beautiful place to spend a couple of hours.
We were taken on a 15-20 mins tour of the tea factory. It is nice to know that tea processing takes less than a day!

Worth spending some time here and joining a guided tour. The guided tours are led by guides who give you lots of information about the tea, how its picked, dried and packed. Worth looking in the shop and having a cup of tea as well.
amazing fields, amazing experience, the tea smells perfect at the factory, and you can buy all flavours you like.

I did three factory tours in one day all accessible by public bus from Nuwara eliya the factory was nice better than macwoods although the guide was better at glenloch I only got one cup of complementary tea which was nice but would of preferred a small batch of samples to taste rather than one big cup!

On our way up to Nuwara Eliya we stopped of at this Tea plantation and factory were we sampled the best BOP tea then had a tour of the factory and leant about the process of how tea is produced once it had been hand picked earlier in the day by ladies. The process and machinery is pretty much the same now as it was nearly 100 years ago, the tea leafes are still selected and picked by hand all by women, and then the drying and pressing process commences within 6 hours of the leafs being picked. We enjoyed the short tour as we now fully understand the process involved in producing tea, and as you'd expect you can buy some tea on the way out.

Before reaching to the tea estate there is a strawberry firm one must visit there. I loved their strawberry pan cakes and the shakes. Everywhere in Sri Lanka we got the best ever fresh fruit juice. Here too the juice is fresh. In the tea estate one can buy tea and they too offer to taste before buy. They offer a tour to the tea processing which i experienced before in Malaysia. But the information regarding the processing and the quality differences are resourceful

Learnt a lot in 30 minute tour of the factory and enjoyed a quick cup of house blend black tea. Good little shop to take home some local product. This is a high-volume tourist destination with a carpark that accommodates buses.
You get good view about how tea is processed and what are are differences between different qualities of tea. Also get cup of very good tea.

Brief tour- it was obvious that the guides had been spouting the same things for the umpteenth time but our girl was still pleasant about it. She didn't even stick around for a tip because she had to go on to the next group already. The shop was packed. The cashier section could do with improvements- there was no sense of where the line ended or began. The free tea tasted better with the lovely cake we bought. All in all, I felt it was about selling tea rather than enlightening us on the tea growing process. We also went on a Saturday, so we didn't see the factory in action.

This is a nice place to visit alone for the free tour (you just can tip which is of course recommended). The tour is quite short (10 min) and then you get a free cup of tea at the end in the restaurant. Tee shop offers a variety of tee (not the cheapest) but bought some anyway to bring home (200 g for 400rp). Drop by for a visit, if it is even just for the cup of tea and the tour!

A lady will come and take you through the tea making process ..which is explained in precisely five minutes. The lady will speak out standard speech with no detailing etc. And then we are taken to their cafe and served hot tea ( great for a rainy day that we happened to be there) You are free to shop around and buy different varieties of Teas...which is the main idea behind this.

Short little tour of the factory and tea making process. Thought we'd actually walk amongst the plantations or at least see the trees up close. This place has so much potential. I would pay for a guided tour of the plantations itself. Free tea, nice gift shop. Definite room for improvement.
This is an old establishment but functioning well ! I commend a vist to all tourists. My wife and I toured with Ceylon Bliss ,great people and very attentive. I would do it again.
The location is awesome. It is one of the many tea factories you will find in this region. You get some awesome ceylon tea but looks little expensive.

The drive from Nawara Eliya to the tea factory was beautiful. Although the children felt quite sick as the roads as quite steep and bendy. The drive is around 30 mins from the main town. The guide at the tea factory was very knowledgable and informative. She talked us through the process in the factory and we saw the tea leaves in action at each stage which was great. We saw some of the tea pickers around the factory outside but would have been even better to see them working in the tea plantation but this was not an option offered to us. We then sampled one cup of tea. Again it would have been nice to have a tea tasting option of a few teas. We bought a few teas from the store at great prices, they had a great selection to choose from. We also had some lunch before we began which was of a tourist style buffet nothing great. Wouldn't suggest you have the lunch here. We visited another tea factory in Ella after visiting Bluefield a few days after and in comparison, Bluefield could do a lot better in what they offer, tea tasting should be offered, and an option to be shown around tea plantation would be nice. A lot more potential is there.
We had some tea but it was very crowded, not enough places to sit down. Sadly it was not stroller friendly. However, the cup of tea was good!

Did not like their attitude as they did not inform us that Italian cuisine is not available. Their Italian restaurant was closed for renovation but it was not mentioned on the hotel's website. Nobody to welcome us to their Thai restaurant at 7pm and staff was not at all helpful. Then we thought of spending time at the hotel Spa and found it to be of very low quality in terms of ambiance and trained staff. The only good place was an Indian restaurant located outside the main block of the hotel but we didn't want to try Indian cuisine.
Nice location. Good guides explain the entire tea processing and gave a cup of ceylon tea as well. Have variety of tea in the shopping place to buy

We had a great stay in Sri Lanka and were really impressed with every other activity, understandhowever this place was terrible. We were first taken on a tour which started off well but as soon as you started asking questions you realized the persons had no knowledge. You are then taken back to the main reception where teas are plonked I from of you. No choice no tasting no experience just put down. When we said we would like to taste some other teas we were immediately told we had to pay, which with the price of everything in Sri Lanka really makes no difference. The service was pathetic, and the toilets disgusting. We ended up leaving and looking for another venue that were a little friendlier and would take us to the tea plantations, which we were rudely told we could walk to on our own if we liked by the Bluefield team. Biggest disappointment on our trip. I would avoid.

a Small place where you can learn about the Process of making tea from the garden to lips. The guides available in the factory gives you a clear picture in the language you can understand and clarifies your queries too. Finally you can end up with a Black tea.
Tee fields, tee factory, restaurant-tasty food, tee shop with many kinds of tee, cheap and expensive variety of tee)

We stop her on the way south and it was fantastic. Our guide was great and took us around the plantations and then into the factory and fully explained the whole process. We then had a free cup of tea at the end and the tea quality was great. A recommended stop and great value with only a tip for the guide.
Nice place to have a cup of ceylon tea and have a look at the tea processing as well. Friendly staff. Play area helps to keep kids occupied.
The entrance is free, you get a guide and tip what you want. Good explain. They offer you 1 cup of tea at the restaurant.
